div.p: THE Mock-Marriage. A COMEDY, ACTED At the THEATRE in DORSET GARDEN, By His MAJESTY's Servants.

q.p: â€” Et Augusto recitantes mense Poetas.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for H. Rhodes, in Fleet-street; J. Harris, in the Poultry; and S. Briscoe, in Russel-street, the Corner of Charles-street, Covent-Garden. 1696.
Advertisement. She Ventures, and He Wins: A New Comedy. Written by a Young Lady.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: NOtwithstanding the many Accidents that concurr'd to the Ruin of this Play, it succeeded above my Expectations: And I must own my self infinitely oblig'd to the Town, in receiving so favourably, what I at first never design'd for the Stage; it being only the Product of some leisure Hours, which indeed might have been worse employ'd. Had I known the Stage as well as one who undertakes to write for it ought, perhaps I might have perform'd better; but I must look on Things of this nature rather as my Diversion than Employment. If those few Friends I have are not disoblig'd herein, I shall have no reason to complain.

As for the Play it self, it is not my Business either to reckon up, or defend the Faults urg'd against it: They who pretend to write by Rule, and at the same time hope to divert the Town, will, I fear, bave but little more than their Labour for their
Pains. Peoples Tastes are different in all Ages; and that which was extreamly well received in the last, will be scarce look'd upon in this; for the Muses, as modest and reserv'd as they are, must suit their Habits to the times, or they will be exploded; To entertain in private, and divert in publick, are two different Talents, and, I believe, both equally difficult.

To conclude, this, with all its Faults, I am now oblig'd to publish; I must confess I think it so mean, that had it been possible I had disown'd it. But the inquisitiveness of some People was so effectual, as to drag me out by force; and I now stand expos'd to the Fury of the Multitude. One great thing laid to my Charge, in the management of the PLAY, is Prolixity (a Fault I will not here again be guilty of) I own it a Miscarriage scarce to be pardon'd, and can impute it to nothing but my unexperience in things of this Nature: But shou'd I ever play the Fool again, it shall be with more Caution and Moderation.

div.head: PROLOGUE: Spoken by Miss. CROSS.
div.l: YOur Servant, Sirs: I'm comeâ€” Nay, why d'ye wear
Such Anger in your Eyes? I vow and swear
T'have put me out; and I am so dismay'd,
I can't remember what I shou'd have said.
I fear, do what I can, you all are come,
Resolv'd upon a Young-Beginners Doom:
And our poor Friend will find you, to his Cost,
Like Birds of Prey, watching a dying Host.
Hard-hearted Men, if I must ask in vain!
I'm sure I ne'er shall trouble you again.
I must confess, he is a Fool t'oppose
One tender Maid 'gainst such a Crowd of Foes;
The captious Beaux's, and the ill-natur'd Wits;
The thinking Criticks, and unthinking Cits:
Those head-strong Judges, 'tis in vain t'emplore 'em;
With well-arm'd Forhead we'll bear all before 'em.
Or are my Fears in vain? I'm sure ere while
You gently did on our Endeavours smile,
When our old Lords, those Giants of the Stage,
Did in wild Fury with our Youth engage.
But David can, as they in shame found true,
Both wear Goliah's Sword, and weild it too.
Be kind then to his Youth, and, for my sake,
Don't all th' Advantages you meet with, take:
'Tis a small Boon I ask; The Poet spare,
Good tender Sirs, in Kindness to the Play'r.
Shall I prevail? I hope I shall. Howe'er,
If you all come resolv'd to be severe,
If he must die, at least he humbly prays
His Judges, to reprieve him for Three Days.

div.head: EPILOGUE: Spoken by Mrs. KNIGHT.
div.l: OF all the Fools, that now infest the Town,
(As we have many) you will meet with none
Detested more by all Judicious Men,
Than the poor Wretch that ventures on the Pen.
All other Fools you pity, or excuse;
But him you're bound in Conscience to misuse.
The Fool of Fortune is your dear Delight;
Ten thousand Pounds a-year can keep all right.
The keeping Fool, what bold Tongue dares accuse?
You may keep any Mistress but a Muse.
The Fool in Office has your daily Grace,
Which you pay not to him, but to his Place.
In short we find (and sure there's something in't)
All Fools are safe, but the poor Fool in Print.
We have a scribling Wretch within, I fear
Whate'er he thinks, will find no better Chear,
Than all his Predecessors met with here.
For th'idle Fool took no care to secure
One single Friend amongst you all, and sure
A Man in his Condition's past all Cure.
I blam'd him for it; but he says he knows
No Favour he can hope for from the Beaux:
For in sincerity he does profess,
He knows not what they are but by their Dress.
For the Wits Voices he wou'd humbly pray,
Did not their Talent lie the other way.
And to the Ladies (to his shame be it said)
He is so modest, he can't show his Head.
Then use him roughly, nip him in the Bud,
He'll grow too sturdy if he's not withstood.
But hold, methinks, I hear some wisely say,
'Tis not your Interest sure to damn the Play.
Well, if y'are kind to this, ere we give o'er,
You'll find we've better for you in our store.
He that sets forth a well-appointed Feast,
Does never at the first produce the best:
If you will be t'our first Endeavours good,
Our next Dish shall be more substantial Food.

div.head: SCENE I. SCENE, A Parlour.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: AND are these all the Diversions this Town affords?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O no, there are an hundred other things, that pass with the same stamp upon 'em; Men are become as fantastical in their Pleasures as their Devotions; we are now a-days grown nice and speculative: Every Man is for abstracting something or other, peculiar to his own Humour, which he varnishes over with the Name of Pleasure, tho' it be in it self never so uncouth and ridiculous: You shall have some whose chief delight lies in reading a Play, with a good Grace, to my Lady, after Dinner, passing a Complement or two upon her Daughter; or, in their absence, sporting with her Lap-dog, perhaps the more sociable Creature of the two.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: These, it may be, are old Fools, sunk beneath the taste of more refined Pleasures, and by Age rendred unfit for any thing else.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, Faith, lusty young Fellows, with brawny backs, and full faces, design'd by Nature for nobler ends, but bebauch'd in the very Cradle; their Mothers made Fools of 'em whilst they are young, and they make Fools of themselves ever after.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But don't these Fools consider in the mean time, how unjust they are both to themselves and their Country? Can they lye so securely at home, whilst all the Youth of Europe are in Arms, and not be rows'd by the neighbouring War, which roars so loud it almost shakes their Houses?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Why, Faith, Ned, the grave Men may talk to 'em of such things, but they have more Wit to believe 'em; 'tis for Men of broken and desperate Fortunes, that have nothing to do in this World, to bid up for the
next; why, an unthinking Canon-bullet may come, and strike our young Hero over the face, and then farewell 1500 a-year.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And yet our Fathers, Bellfont, who knew the worth of Life as well as we, in foreign Fields, chose rather to spend their days, than sleep in lazy Peace at home, when the English Valour singly cou'd oppose the growing Greatness of our haughty Neighbours, and make 'em bend beneath our stronger Virtue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, ay, there have been those days, when a scar or two were thought as necessary to compleat a Man's Physiogmony, as a beard; but that was before patches came in fashion. Our Fathers were rude, ill-bred fellows, Ned, of Souls as ill-fashion'd as their Cloaths, that knew not how to put a right value upon Life, because not sweeten'd with those softer Pleasures, which we their famous Off-spring, the bold Adventures of this happier Age, dar'd first discover.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Pleasures indeed; but, O how much they've cost us! Our Fame and Virtue given in exchange, may make us curse the Purchase; but hang 'em, let's leave 'em to their own Folly and Repentance: And, prithee, tell me, Bellfont, I hope some Men of Sense are still to be found; for if the Town is composed of such as these, I had best back to Flanders again; 'twill be more troublesome to me, than Winter-Quarters in an Enemy's Country.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, Faith, never think of Flanders, so long as there is good Wine, good Friends, and handsome Whores to be had; for as for the honest Women, as our Friend Willmot saith, they are not worth our thoughts.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: For shame, Harry, what, talk of Whores so early in the morning? See if Fairly doth not blush at it. Hark you, Ned, if you wear those looks always, you'll never rise to any higher service with the Women, than holding their Fans, or, perhaps, buckling their Shoes upon occasion. Throw aside that stiff Spanish Gravity, and appear like thy Self, brisk, gay, and witty, as Nature has design'd thee, and do not wrong thy Youth thus.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: All in good time, Frank, all in good time; two or three more of thy loose wanton humour wou'd turn the World upside down.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: With all my heart, I long to see th'other side of it, this is so crowded with Knaves and Fools, that there is hardly any room left for Men of Sense to stir in.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I find, indeed, Frank, my Landlady has drawn thee to the Life, in her Character she hath given me of thee.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Damn her, old Jezebell, she has been corrupting her Neece with some of her grave Instructions too, she'd never be so reserv'd else; I have ever-minded it, those envious old Devils, who are damn'd by Age to an insensibility of Pleasure themselves, are always for disappointing it in others. Butâ€”

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: But what, Mr. Willmot? I have heard you, your wicked devices will fall upon your own head.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Dear Landlady, how does thy leathern face this morning? Let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Stand off, you rude Man, I wonder you are not ashamed to appear in my house; as I am honest, Gentlemen, he is e'en a Termagent, my Maids tremble at the very sight of him; if he comes within twenty yards of the house, they are unfit for business three hours after. Stand off, I say; if he goes on at this rate, my own Person won't be secure; but, Sir, have a care, there is Law to be had against Ravishers.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Alas, alas! five and fifty will secure thy Person, old Eve, better than all the Laws in the Land; but if thou would'st beget a good Understanding betwixt me and thy pretty Neece, I shou'd not care much if I held up my hand in all the Courts in England.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Out, you Beast! wou'd you have me turn Bawd at last?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Why not, you old Fool? Thou art good for nothing else. I can't imagine why they, who are thrust off the Stage of Pleasure themselves, shou'd not be assisting to those that are upon it, and so promote the good Work, tho' they can't be Actors in it.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: You hear him, Gentlemen; but 'tis no matter, ease and plenty have made him wanton, he'll be of another mind one day. There, Sir, [To Willmot] there's a Letter for you, I undertook to deliver it, though you do not deserve so much from me.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Why, did not I tell you, Gentlemen, she'd make an excellent Bawd, she's Mistress of one branch of the Faculty already: Look here, she has a good hand at Conveyances. Here, old Sybil, read it thy self.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I will so, if I have my eyes about me. Let me see, How's this!

body.p: MY Husband has been abroad these two days, and will not return till Saturday; if you have half the Love you pretend, you will not neglect so favourable an Opportunity: The Bearer may prove a necessary Instrument, and will deserve Encouragement,

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Which thou shalt most assuredly have, my dear Embassadress. Well, what Gratuity, ha! a new Gown, Scarf, or a Suit of Linen? Come, prithee tell me which would'st thou have? Or now I think of it, a new Sett of Teeth wou'd do better than any thing.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p:
Stand off, Sir, and don't provoke me, I'd have you to know I'm a Gentlewoman; my Husband, God bless him, if he had liv'd, might have been an Alderman e'er now, and I to do this. No, Sir, I received it of the Instrument, as you call him, this morning; he thought you had
still lodg'd here; but you shall receive the next your self for me; and as for your Pimp, if I catch him again, I'll take order that my Maids shall give him the Encouragement he deserves; a young Rogue, that has scarce wip'd his Mother's Milk off his Chaps, and he to turn the Devil's Solicitor! Lord! Lord! what will this World come to!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No more Reflections, good Beldame; but lay your hand upon your heart, and tell me, if your business was never manag'd by such a Lawyer; remember my Lord Goodland's Page, that was to cry, Hem! if any one appear'd: Come, come, these Gentlemen shall know all.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I defie thee, and all thy Malice, thou wicked Slanderer, though by day and night I'll be even with you, or I'll be the Table-talk of the whole Town.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, don't be angry, good Landlady, but let us come to the business; prithee document thy Neece a little better, she is young and giddy I confess, but must needs hearken to thee, both as thou art an old Woman, and her Aunt; if thou wilt but bring the business about, thou know'st my meaningâ€”

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: No, no, good Devil, keep off, I shall sacrifice none of my Flesh and Blood to you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: None of thine! I want it not; 'tis for Flavia I pine, and languish; and if thou hast no Compassion on me, I shall die out-right.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Why, Faith, the sooner the better; for I know no remedy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well then, since thou art so inexorable, I proclaim open War against thee; thou shalt not have a Monkey left to play with a-days, or a Lap-dog to sport with a-nights; not an old Beaux to hand thee to Church, or bow to thee in the Play-house; I'll watch thee as narrowly as thy old Husband ever did; if any one offers thee the least Civility, I'll challenge him; and if he dares refuse the Combat, post him up for a Coward; till by degrees I have so exercised thee, that thou fallest sick of the yellow Jaundice, and at last dy'st in Bedlam: What say'st thou, wilt thou compound yet?

sp.speaker: Land,
sp.p: No, I'll the first; but, to be even with you, may the hot desires of boiling Youth, and the impotence of old Age, be your continual Plagues; may all your Mistresses be kind, but want the blessings of Opportunity to yield themselves up to you; may some unexpected Accident still cross your Expectations at the very point of Enjoyment; may all your Wishes be as eager, as your Endeavours vain; and, to allay the Fires your amorous hopes have kindled, may you fly to some old Weatherbeaten Sinner, that may corrupt your Body, and blast your Reputation; may you in the heighth of Youth drop into the Diseases of old Age, and at last die in an Hospital, and so farewell; for I will have my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha; Faith, Willmot, I believe it is the wisest way to be reconcil'd; for whatever you think of Flavia, shou'd she spoil your Designs upon Clarinda, I believe a little from that side wou'd sensibly touch you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No, no, Clarinda has more Wit than to hearken to her, besides my pretences to her have nothing but Honour in 'em, cou'd I persuade that young Gypsie to believe me.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Very honourable indeed, when in the heighth of your Courtship you are upon a double Scent: True Love is like real Friendship, it can admit but of one Object; for otherwise it loses its name, and becomes meer Flattery and Ostentation.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, hold there, Ned, I grant you a Man can take but one, for better for worse; but where there is a full stock of Love, others surely may put in for the overflowings: Tis true, none but the elder Son shou d lay lay claim to the Inheritance, and yet the younger may reasonably expect some, by Gifts and Legacies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And you, I fear, are for disposing of so many, that your main Estate will be scarce responsible.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Then I'll call in my Friends to my assistance; but of this we'll discourse more over a Glass of Wine at my Lord Goodland's, and the two young Ladies shall judge of our performances. What think you, Fairly? Will you submit yourself to Marina's Judgment?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes, if I cou'd but hope she thought as favourably of me, as I do of her; but I hear our English Ladies have thrown off that freedom and openness of humour they have been so celebrated for, and are become too nice and reserved, even to affectation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And yet that reservedness you seem to condemn in our Ladies, it is no more than necessary. We begin to use more severity towards them than the very Spaniard; he by his restraint secures 'em from the worst of Vices, we expose and mis-represent the very best of their Vertues; nay, the noblest of the whole Sex have been sometimes stigmatized in a Lampoon for that very Action which deserv'd a Panegyrick.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I thought those Lampooners Province lay on the other side; does the whole Town afford 'em such thin Diet, that they are forc'd to prey upon Vertue to satisfie their ravenous Appetite?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O damn 'em for ill-bred Curs, that love to leave the lawful Scent, and fall soul on forbidden Game; sullen mischievous Beasts, that have nothing of Satyrs in 'em, but the deformity, that by a strange Art of Chymistry, can change the purest of Gold into the basest of Metals, and draw the rankest Poisons out of the wholesomest Herbs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why, as ill a Character as you have given of these People, Bellfont, Sir Arthur within thinks it no diminution to his Honour to be reckon'd in the number.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, I must confess he has ill Nature enough to entitle him to it.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And as he thinks, Wit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A little will qualifie him.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You two are always quarelling I find, Willmot

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: O, he must be kept at some distance, or he'd grow too sawcy and familiar.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Certainly never had one Man such a variety of Humours, so directly opposite to one another; they say he is Master of a great Estate, and yet he has seldom a peny in his Pocket; a great Lover of Women's Company, and yet so slovenly, that he is sometimes scarce to be endur'd in Men's; this hour so obliging and complaisant, that you wou'd take him for a meer Courtier; the next, so rough and intractable, that there is no dealing with him; and though he pretends to an open intercourse and familiarity with many of the Nobility, yet doth his Acquaintance lye no less amongst the very Scoundrels of the Town.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: And I believe him equally ridiculous to both; these make choice of him for their Prey, and th'other for their Mirth: He is a Glove for both hands.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And yet handsome on neither; a Fool that will be frequently thrusting himself into good Company, tho' he is sure to spoil it; next to his Uncle Sir Simon, I believe him the most extraordinary Person this Town can afford.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: That is indeed a Master-piece, an Ideot that is mightily affronted he is not rais'd up to the Nobility; nay, so extravagantly vain and supercilious, that he thinks it infinitely beneath his Quality so much as to look upon any one under the Title of Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very fond of his Wife I hear.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And withal very jealous.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You know best with what Reason, VVillmot; for I hear whatever Opinion he may have of a Plebeian, she hath no very mean one of you.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Why, truly she is so prudent, as not to esteem Men according to the airy trifles of Fortune, but the more substantial gifts of Nature.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And to show her Judgment, has fix'd on your Person as the Object of her Favour.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I must confess we have frequently spent some hours together, and, I believe, to both our satisfactions.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, to your credit be it spoken, I hear she has almost quench'd that thirst after variety, that wandring inconstant humour, you have been hitherto so famous for. Prithee, what has she about her entertains thee so long?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Why, I esteem her much for the same reason some People love a Cat or Monkey, because they are mischievous: She has a sort of ill-natur'd Wit in her, that you will be forc'd to admire, tho' you are sure to suffer under it: She has learn'd her Master Ovid's Lesson most exactly; for she'll always sharpen the Appetite by some unlucky contrivance or other, that shall be sure to bawk your Expectation for the present, and send you back more eager in your Wishes than you came; so that by that time she is pleased to give her self into your Arms, you come fir'd with double Vigour, and shall find new Charms that are more engaging, because seemingly reap'd in danger.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A politick Quality enough in a Mistress: She knows thy tambling Humour, and therefore uses thee accordingly. But I wonder we hear nothing of Sir Arthur this Morning: He uses to be calling for his Chocolate ere this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Perhaps he hears that Willmot is with thee; and therefore cares not to appear. What was the ground of your Quarrel last Night, Frank? I found you mighty high.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The Fool wou'd needs pretend to have been something too familiar with a Lady of my Acquaintance I met with in the Play-house, and give the Company an account of the Time when and where; when, to my own Knowledge, she has scarce been in London four Days; and I am sure never saw it before in her life.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: What wont such vain Fops affirm! But, hold; I believe I hear him coming. Prithee, Frank, do thou withdraw a little; for I fear he'll not come in, if he sees thee here.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I will so. But try to bring in the Subject of our Quarrel in your Discourse, if you can: We shall hear if he is in the same Humour now, he was in last Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur within.]
sp.p: Landlady, good-morrow: Is Ned Fairly within?

sp.speaker: Landlady within.]
sp.p: Yes, Sir Arthur; he's in the Dining-Room.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Here he comes: Fox, to the Hole. Sir Arthur, good-morrow: I thought a Man addicted to Study like your self, cou'd not have lain, with patience, so long in Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Why faith, Ned, the Fumes of last Night's Wine have rais'd Foggs in my Brain this Morning. But where do you dine to day?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Where I hope we shall have your good Company: It is my Lord Goodland's Birth-day, which I hear he celebrates most Nobly: You are invited, Sir Arthur, amongst the rest.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Faith I'm sorry I can't be there; I made a Promise to a Lady, that was mighty importunate with me last night, to bring two or three of my new Songs, and dine with her to day: But I may come and take a Glass after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You'll oblige the Company, Sir Arthur. But what, may I be so bold as to ask who this Lady is? The same, I sansie, VVillmot was so uncivil as to quarrel with you about last night.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: The very same, Ned: But was there ever such an unmannerly Puppy, to tell me to my Face the Lady was a Stranger to me, when I'm sure we have been familiarly acquainted these twelve Months!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And yet he positively affirms she never saw London 'till within these four Days.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: VVilmot is a Rascal, and they are all Fools that hearken to him: Had I thought he wou'd have answer'd me, I had challeng'd him; but I know him a Coward, and think him beneath my Anger.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir, he's a Man of Honour, and they say, when provok'd, has a sharp Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Honour, Sir! What mean you? Not so much as Sir Arthur Stately, I hope: And as for a Sword, mine's as good a Blade as his can be.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I doubt it not; and in as good Hands, that can manage it as cleanly.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Clean, Sir? I confess I have not wash'd 'em to day: But what's that to you? Had you nothing else to observe? I hate those Men that still expose the Failings of their Friends, but bury their Vertues in silence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Do you take me for your Nurse, Sir Arthur, to mind whether your Face is clean every morning? tho', I confess, you wou'd do well to keep a Valet for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come, come, no more of that, Harry; when Sir Arthur has time to consider, he'll be of your Mind; 'till then, we'll leave him to the pursuit of his Pleasures, and with him success amongst the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Success! he deserves it not; and 'tis impossible he shou'd obtain it: She that can grant him a Court'sie, will hardly deny one to the Devil. Were I a Woman, I shou'd take a Black-moor for an Angel to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Malice, by Hell! meer Malice, and Repining at my good Parts! And yet know, Sir, there are Ladies in Town bright as the Day, and sweeter than the Morning, that dare be familiar with my Person, in a better Place than I shall name at present, whilst you are consuming your Wits in a dull rhiming Ditty, Sir, below, and tuning it to your lamentable squeaking Cats-guts: And so I leave you; for know, I scorn you more than you envy me.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: re-entring.] Hold, good Sir Arthur; pray hear me a Word first before you go.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: The Devil! VVillmot here! Nay thenâ€” But hang him, they dare not in Honour let him draw upon me; besides, my Uncle may be call'd upon occasion (Aside.) Well, Sir, what have you to say?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: You are design'd for the Lady this Morning, I hear?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: A plague take him: Upon that String still! And what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: My Love, Sir, that's all; and withal tell her from me, Since Nature work'd so very violenty in her, as to force her to sacrifice her Honour to her Inclinations, she cou'd not have pick'd out a fitter Person than the Worthy Sir Arthur Stately.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: O Sir, your Servant. What means he?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: The Mirrour of Knighthood! All this while Sir Arthur is endeavouring to get from 'em, but they detain him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And Top-Gallant of Generosity!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: That Pyramid of Learning!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And Monster of Good-nature!

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: The Glory of the Young!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And Envy of the Old!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, by your leave, Sir, your Modesty must be patient a little: I can never do too much to wipe off the Injury I did you last Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: None at all, Sir, I vow to Gad: 'Pray', Sir, excuse me.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: You shall have Justice. First, for his outside, that compleat shape.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And sprightly Air.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: That rising Nose.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: And radiant Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That graceful Front.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And ruddy Cheeks.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Those Milk-white Teethâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And pouting Lips.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Hold Sir, I've a Sword.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Lock it up, you'll lose it else.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: And shallâ€”

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Pick your Teeth with it?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Run you through the Guts.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Dare you use it?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Wou'd I durst.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Dost thou hear me, thou vain Fop, thou Lover in imagination only; had'st thou no body else to abuse, no Sempstress's Daughter, or Suburb-Mistress, no Merchant's Wife, or Captain's Sinner, People that have no Reputation, and yet want none; but your rude Tongue must play with the fair Honour of one unknown: A Lady too, by Heaven, whose Maiden-thoughts, did they once start aside, warm'd by Desire and youthful Blood, on sight of such a filthy lump of Lewdness, wou'd recoil back, and cool again to Vertue.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Hold, Willmot, now you are too unconscionable; the Knight is sensible of it already: What shou'd he do with a Mistress, write Anagrams upon her Name, or Posies for a Ring? He dares appear no where abroad with her; not at the Play-house, for there the Orange-wenches wou'd ridicule him; nor at Church, where the Dogs wou'd bark at him; besides, he can't tell how to write a Billet-deux genteely, unless it be in Rhime: And you know, Sir Arthur, 'tis ten to one, but she'd pin that at your back again the next time you came to visit her.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I know my own Worth; and all you can say, shall never lessen my good Opinion of my self; and so I leave you: May Pride and ill Nature be your daily Companions. Exit. Roger.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir, ha, ha, ha: A pleasant Scene, this.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Your Worship's Pleasure?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Thou hast dogg'd many a Woman upon occasion, and that very cunningly: Follow me now Sir Arthur; house him, and learn his business there, if possible; nay, make haste, thou'lt loose him else.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I fly to serve you, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Now if the Rogue succeeds, and no doubt but he will, shall we know what Women these are, that have such an honourable esteem for his Person; some dirty Landress or other, my Life on't.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I confess it will be worth our discovery: 'Twill be a mortification both to him and Sir Simon, who wou'd utterly discard him, shou'd he know he touch'd the Lip of any thing that was not honourable.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: May the Event answer our Expectations: But prithee what Lady is this, whose Honour thou hast so zealously defended?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Why, 'Faith, one that may have no more than Sir Arthur wou'd allow her, for ought I know: She has Wit and Beauty enough for a Whore; and if her Honesty can't keep pace with both, she may be what he fancy'd her; but as yet I have better thoughts of her. In short, it was Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Devil 'twas!

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: The very same, Man.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis strange he did not know her, being so near a Neighbour!

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Not so, considering she came but last Friday, and has been scarce twice abroad e'er since.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I fancy, Frank, this piece of Generosity, did she hear of it, must needs do more with her than a whole Year spent in formal Courtship.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Hear of it! Not for the World: 'Twill make her proud and careless of her own Honour, when she thinks she has got a Champion to maintain it; besides, I shall be laugh'd at for a meer Knight-errant, and the Avenger of distress'd Damosels. No, I had rather be her Ladyship's Pimp, than Hector; therefore no Words of it if you love me: But how Sir Arthur will carry't off when he sees her, will be worth our Observation.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Like one who has his Sins set full before him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I warrant it worth all our other Mirth; but, come, 'tis time we were there.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Allons, Fairly. Now for Marina.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did you never speak to her yet?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Not since my return from Travel: 'Tis true, before I went, we grew up into an innocent Familiarity, grounded upon the Friendship of our Parents; nay, sometimes her un-experience wou'd let fall something, my eager hopes did then interpret the Signs of Love: But she was young, and, as my Fears now tell me, scarce knew the Name.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I warrant thee, Man, Girls of Fourteen know as much as their Mothers; and, at Fifteen, are of as ripe Experience.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Well, Fortune be my Friend.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Be thy own, Ned; and then a Fig for fortune.

div.stage: Fairly, Belfont go out; and as Willmot follows, he sees Flavia, who appears at the other side of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Good Lord! I have been crossing my self, and devoutly saying my Pray'rs this Morning, for fear of the Devil, and the very first thing I meet proves to be him. Well, I'll pray no more, if these be their effects.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: No, Child, you know Prayers without Charity are always inffectual; and 'till thou hast some for me, thine must necessarily prove so.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Why, Good Sir, wherein do you stand in need of it? You are sound and firm in body, as I take it.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Yes, 'Faith, and in good health; try me else.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Softly, softly, Sir, and I believe in want of nothing. You wear good Cloaths, and, I dare say, feed well: Your Face speaks as much.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Dost thou like it then?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Yes, as I wou'd a well-drawn Picture; that feeds the sight with Pleasure afar off; but approach near it, and its Beauty's lost.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: The Devil thou dost: A pretty Comparison, 'Faith. Dost thou take me for a piece of Arras; a thing in a Frame, set to adorn your Ladyship's Closet; the silent Witness of your secret lewdness?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: No hold there, Sir, I've scarce so good an Opinion of you; so far from thinking you wou'd conceal what you see, that I believe you wou'd tell more than you know.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: So far from that, Sweet-heart, that let a Lady be kind to me overnight, and 'Faith, I forget it quite next Morning; nay, I scarce think of her, or her business, ever after.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: A fine Commendation this, and a great Encouragement. 'Pray' Sir, forget me then; nay, Sir, keep farther off, or I shall call my Aunt.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I had rather thou should'st call the Devil; he'd be less trouble, and sooner learn his Duty. Well, what say'st thou? By those wanton Eyes, and trembling Lips, those glowing Cheeks, by all thy soft Desires, say shall I not? My Love, my Angel! how can'st thou be thus cruel?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: This Afternoonâ€”

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Speak where, and make me happy.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: In my Lord Goodland's Grove, adjoining to my Aunt's Garden.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: 'Twas made on purpose: At Four then I'll expect you.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Three if you love me.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: By this Kiss I do: Ten thousand Sweets are lodg'd in't.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Well, you'll forget now.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I shall be damn'd then.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Till thenâ€”

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.l: Farewell: All my best Hopes wait on you. Exit Flavia.
Women were born to be subdu'd: In vain
They strive t'oppose the nobler Creature Man:
Their own Desires at length will make 'em yield,
And first or last they all must quit the Field.

div.head: SCENE I. Scene, Lady, Goodland's House.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: WEll, well, Cousin, I say still, London for my Money: If my Mother catches me in the Country again in haste, may I look as old as she does; or what is worse, marry the Fool her Wisdom, has pick'd out for me, and be kept there all the days of my life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Marry, I suppose you design nothing else; 'tis her Will, and she must be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why, 'Faith, that's e'en as I please to order it: I grant you, were there a scarcity of Men, and consequently a danger of my dying a Maid, I might upon reasonable Terms be brought to submit; but as long as there is such a variety, Lawyers with great Estates, and Courtiers with none at all; elder Brothers with heavy Heads, and younger with light Purses; Citizens, Soldiers, Players, and Poets: If he ever gets me between a pair of Sheets, I'll be damn'd to sowre-Milk, and Whey-butter, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You're not in earnest sure?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: By my Virginity, but I am.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now, in my Eyes, the Country is not so disagreeable, unless an easie retir'd Life, remov'd from the Clamours and Vices of the Town, may be reckon'd as such.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, hold you there, good Cousin, the Country has its Noises too, tho', perhaps, not so loud and frequent; yet I'm sure far more odious. What think you of a Consort of Hounds for a Serenade ev'ry Morning, that raises your good Spouse by Four-a-Clock, who leaves you to nothing but the vain Wishes of a better Bed-fellow: It may be you drop a-sleep again, and dream of one; but scarce has your Imagination shap'd him to Desires, before a a Flock of well dispos'd Geese frightens your fancy'd Lover from your Arms, and secures your Body, that Temple of Chastity, from Pollution; so that you have not the opportunity of cuckolding him, tho' it be only in a Dream.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nor had I one, wou'd I desire it; so much shou'd I be his; so truly the Servant of his Pleasures, that I'd esteem each guilty thought a Rebel that dar'd to wander from him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: True, but it must be one that I cou'd love, and that knew how to deserve me; not your dull Country Ass, that makes no difference betwixt his Wife and Horse; who tho' he has Tongue as big as one of his Calves, can entertain me in Discourse with nothing, but the price of Corn and Hay, or rotten Sheep and lowsie Hogs; that confines me to an old House, the ill contriv'd labour of some of his Ancestors, who came over forsooth with VVilliam the Conqueror: my Company, an old Aunt, or ill-favour'd Sister; or perhaps the Parson after Dinner, who is to tell me the meaning of his last Sermon, and sometime a piece of News six months old, pick'd out of the mouldy Papers he lights his Pipes with. No, no, my Father, Peace rest with him, left me moderately rich; and, or I am flatter'd, I have my share of Beauty; if then any thing above a Justices Clerk, dare be troubled with me here, when I go back again to VVarwick-shire, to spend my Time and Money in Pultisses for sore Throats, Plaisters for Scabby Heads, and broken Shins, the Devil shall be wiser than I take him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, you are learned, Cousin; but let us wave this Discourse till VVillmot comes; he shall bear a part in it: I fancy by that guilty blush, you can set down satisfied with him and all his faults.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If he has no more, than I yet perceive, he will not find me very intractable; but I must know him better first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I dare swear he loves you heartily.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If he may be believ'd himself, he does indeed; for he had the impudence to tell me so the very first time he saw me; tho' I fancy there are many other Ladies in Town, can say as much of him: he is one of those that falls in Love with every new Face they meet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He has indeed had the Name of a great Libertine; but you know Wedlock is a Mortifying State, and they say a great cooler of the Blood.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But I'll mortifie him before, or my Wits shall fail me; for when once I give my Hand, I resign all my Power: Marriage in many respects is like Death, you may make what conditions you please before the Ceremony; but as the Parson finds you, he leaves you, there's no Reprieve to be had.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If it's so dangerous, I think them the wisest that keep farthest from it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For the same reason therefore. you shou'd abstain from those Meats that please the Pallat most, for fear of a Surfet, or what is worse, Poysons that may be lodg'd in 'em: no, no Marina, Flesh and Blood sometime or other will be craving, and must be satisfy'd, otherwise we do a violence to Nature, who tells us that we are imperfect pieces, like tender Plants expos'd to th' fury, and the rude blasts of bold malicious Tongues, till our blest Fortunes have at length remov'd us into the Arms of kind, and loving Husbands; there we shoot up, and like the tender Vine, warm'd in the Embraces of the faithful Elm, we join our Loves and sweetly grow together; and when at length we die, we leave behind us a Memory that shall perfume our Ashes.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, here's Mr. VVillmot come in, and I believe has been hunting after you, for he has run his Nose into ev'ry corner of the House.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O let him hunt on, 'twill get him a Stomach to his Dinner.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Are any with him?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes Madam, Mr. Fairly and Mr. Bellfont.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yes, Cousin, Fairly, does it startle you? What think you of him for an Husband?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As of all others; but why that Question?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Because Fame speaks him an Accomplish'd Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She is seldom in the right, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I must confess I have seen him; and to my thinking, his Person promises nothing extraordinary; his Conversation too, they say is no way grateful.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To Wanton Womens Ears perhaps it is not, he knows not how to entertain 'em with a Discourse of this or that Lady, wantonly caught with such a Lord, or reckon up all the new Faces that appear at Court, who 'twas that sqeak'd last night behind the Lobby; what such an one had for her Maidenhead, and how oft she had sold it, things that please none but Fools that live on Scandal; but to all Modest Ears, his words are sweet as the blest Raptures of departing Saints, whose eager Souls are going to possess the long expected Crown of all their Virtues.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Marina, have I caught you? I shou'd take you to be one of those Saints by your Rapture, but I believe yours has more of the Flesh than Spirit in it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What mean you, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What mean you to play the Hypocrite thus? come, come, I guess'd as much before, and what I said was only to try you, tho' I confess, I did not think you'd wince so very soon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, since you have Entrapp'd me, I do love him, equal to Life, and my best hopes of Heaven; more than the Souldier Honour, or the Miser his secret Treasure; more than a new-made Mother, the first dear Pledge of all her Fruitful Joys.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A pat Confession truly, great pitty 'tis he was not Witness to't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, when I stoop so low, and vilely sue him to take me to his Arms, may I grow loath'd as Whores and Drunkards; whatever Fortune has design'd me, I'll still retain that modest Virgin-Pride, which adds new Charms to Beauty, and makes our Youth more lovely.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, my Lord.

div.stage: Enter Lord Goodland, Fairly, and Willmot.

sp.speaker: Ld. Good.
sp.p: Here, where are you? Thinking of Husbands, my life on't; first how to get, and then Cuckold 'em. Here, Mr. Fairly, here's an old Friend of yours, that's grown a strapper since you left England; ay, there to 'em, so well said.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: She's grown indeed, but like a blushing Rose, whose opening Bud promis'd a World of Beauty; but being full blown, exceeds our Expectations.

sp.speaker: Ld. Good.
sp.p: That's well said again, adod, you are a meer Courtier, I wou'd not be a young Girl in your way for something. See if she does not blush; a meer puling Wench, she'll ne're have so much Fire in her as her Mother had.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, a Youthful Lovers Arms, brisk as I'm told your Lordship was in your younger days, will quickly warm her.

sp.speaker: Ld. Good.
sp.p: So, my mad Neece still, and I faith thou art in the right; but a Pies on't, none but Fools and Mad-men will have any thing to say to you upon that score now, your own Pride and Self-conceit has quite spoil'd your Market; a Lover is but a more Genteel Name for an Ass; for twenty pound to a Fidle-string, but you make him such before you have done.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do you hear that, Sir, know what you was born to, and tremble.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: Yes my little Circe, I do so; thou shalt make me what Beast thy fancy likes best, so thou wilt make me thine: I'll bed thee under all the shapes in Aesop, and beget a new Race of Monsters to People the Land of the Moon, and thou and I will Reign King and Queen there.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No Sir, such odd ways of Courtship have been out of fashion ever since the old Heathen Poets fell asleep; I'd rather have a Cobler for my Bed-fellow, than a Swan, or Satyr: your Worship may be a Bull, if you please, a day times; but at night you must be a Man, or I shall fix a pair of Horns on your Head that will be very uneasie.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: Well, no Man knows what he may be before he dies; but if I do wear Hornsâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ill hang my Maid's Petticoats upon 'em.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: That may chance to raise an Itch in me, will be very troublesom.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O no Sir, if you are of so quick a Scent, to prevent all mischief, we'll muzzle you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (Aside) How eagerly he views me! Surely he wou'd look through me; which if he can, he'll find an Heart within ty'd to his Love, and triumph in my weakness.

sp.speaker: Ld. Good.
sp.p: Well, but Mr. Fairly, old Men love to enquire, and you Travellers often love to relate the Stories of your Travels, or shall we suspend our Curiosity till after Dinner, 'twill then serve instead of Musick, and crown our lusty Glasses.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: My Lord, neither my Adventures, or Observations, were so curious, as necessary; I travell'd not to fill my Mouth, but enrich my Understanding; and took more care to know my self exactly, than the Countries I pass'd through.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Did you meet with no Rarities abroad, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: None exceeding those I've seen at home, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They say the Italian Ladies are Fair to a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p:
They are indeed; but yet they must give the English leave to lead the way: I must confess I saw at Venice a perfect Beauty, as such esteem'd, to whom the Nobles su'd, and at whose Feet the Souldier, in the full pride
of all his Glorious Conquests, laid down his useless Arms, unable to defend him against the force of her Commanding Beauty: the Wealthy Merchant too acknowledg'd he had found a Jewel here at home, worth all his Indies; and the Scholar invok'd no other Goddess in his Verse, whose tuneful Notes sung nothing but her Praises.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What have I heard? O I am lost for ever! (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I suppose Sir, after the Description you have given, to ask if you was smitten amongst the rest, wou'd be to question if you are a Man or no.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: No, Madam, I cou'd safely look upon her, and view her in all her Glories; my Heart was gone before, the happy Subject of a far Nobler Conquest; nor wou'd I seek a Mistress out in Italy, who had left behind me here in England, a Miracle worth all their boasted Saints; a Piece so Fair, so full of Goodness, that the bold Poets daring Fancy cou'd never form a sweeter.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: There's for you Mr. VVillmot, when will you speak such a Speech in Praise of your Mistress?

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: O Madam, I'm yet but a beginner, in time you may have me come to this and a great deal more, make Songs upon you shortly; nay, perhaps a Play or two, where you may expect to find your self an Empress at least.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You can promise well I know; but you Men in matters of Love, are like humoursome Children, who cry for this or that Gewgaw for the present, but are scarce acquainted with it, before 'tis discarded, and then your Fancies are wholly bent on something else: don't I know you have the Name of the greatest Wanton in Town; don't all the World talk loudly of your Virtues?

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: Why, faith, Madam, I confess some People have been too busie with my Reputation; but you know they who dare believe what the World says, dare be mad; 'tis never in the right.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well then, to disprove it, do but satisfie me, you can keep honest for one whole week together; I mean, so far as to conceal your Wanderings; do but be private in your sins, and I'll believe you.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: A week, Madam, ay, if there were as many days in it as there are in a whole year.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But if I find you falseâ€”

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: Let all the Sehool-boys in Town piss upon me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Good.
sp.p: A desperate undertaking, Mr. VVillmot; she'll have a close Eye upon you.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: I dare her worst my Lord; phoo, I can live without eating so long as that upon occasion, and the Devil's in't, if I can't do t'other thing as well.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Both alike I believe.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: The event will convince you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Good.
sp.p: Mr. Bellfont, welcom; we want Sir Simon yet

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he is below with several other Gentlemen, that are come to pay their respects to your Lordship's Birth-day.

sp.speaker: Ld. Good.
sp.p: The more the merrier, come Gallants let to Dinner; I'll there show you, what 'tis has made me count so many years, and teach you to live till you are all as old as I am.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We wait upon your Lordship. Exeunt omnes, praeter Marina.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's this I feel thus rising in my Breast? Have I room there for any thing but Love? From whence then this new Guest? Is't Jealousie? jealous of whom? And why must I repine at his just Praises of anothers Beauty, since 'tis a Debt that's due to her deservings? But then he loves her, and is again belov'd; and all my Virgin-hopes must lye forever bury'd in despair.

But see he's return'd; does then his Love, like mine, drive him to Solitudes? O tho' I esteem his presence dearer than these two Eyes with which I view him, yet I'll withdraw and hide my shame; for surely let me do what I can, my Tongue will prove a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Peace to your Meditations, Madam; they must certainly be extraordinary that cou'd entertain you thus alone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, they were very melancholy; for I was thinking of an unhappy Maid deceiv'd in her first Love.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Unhappy indeed; for no disappointments are so heavy as those of Lovers: But who was he that cou'd deceive her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: One whom I may still allow blameless, because ignorant of her Passion; and therefore now Servant to another Lady, who, for ought I know, is preferable to my Friend in nothing but the possession of his Love.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And does she then admit of his Addresses?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There, Sir, indeed, you puzzle me; tho' I must confess he is so deserving, so full of Worth, that to think otherwise, wou'd be to think her most ingrateful: Too true, I fear for my Friend's Quiet, she does esteem him, who's therefore left to all the Miseries of a despairing Lover.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You speak a noble pity of her Sufferings; and I cou'd almost wish my self wretched like her, to be thus pity'd by you: What say you, Madam; suppose you shou'd behold me in all the Torments of an hopeless Love, cou'd you let fall one sigh in pity of my Fate?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, so much I see in her the Miseries of unhappy Love, tho' you yourself, were him whom I shou'd hate, the Cause of her Misfortunes; yet wou'd I bear more than a Stranger's share in all your Sufferings, and ne'er be wanting in my best Wishes for your Happiness.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I'm sure without 'em I shou'd never find it: but dare you rise no higher than to unprofitable Wishes for me? Do but look kindly on me, and I'll venture to ask for something more; Love, noble Love, to that I wou'd aspire, if all the Services my Youth can pay are able to deserve it; nay, do not frown, nor turn in anger from me: Indeed 'tis just you shou'd; for what have I can make me hope to merit such a Treasure? And yet Ambition never was thought a Crime in Love: Why was you made thus excellently fair, if Men must not admire you? A Paradise, where all the Sweets of Nature forever flourish, and each ravish'd Sense sits at an everlasting Feast; where no rude blasts of Lusts or Pride dare blow, but Innocence and Truth, sweet as the Arabian Winds, protect your Beauties.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: aside.] O why must my deceitful Tongue condemn those very words, which to my ravish'd Ears, strike far more sweet than Musick?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Had I the Eloquence of all Men in me, or cou'd in softest numbers court the Vertues, my busie Tongue shou'd dwell upon your Praises, till time it self stood still, and weary Nature sunk down into Eternity; but as I am, I ne'er must hope to find Words equal to my Thoughts, or fit to bear the Message of my Mind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, this is not noble in you to play thus with my weakness, and wound my Ears with the smooth Flatteries of your cunning Sex; therefore forgive me if I dare hear no more.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: O stay one moment; for by just Heav'n I swear, if Heav'n that will strike dumb a perjur'd Tongue, I never did conceive one guilty Thought to wrong your Goodness: Cou'd you but look into my Breast, you there wou'd find Fire so chast, so holy, that Hymen's Lamp can ne'er boast a purer: 'Tis true, your Love as yet I dare not hope for, till by my Services I have convinc'd you; yet give me leave to hope I may be happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: aside.] I shou'd not grant; and yet I can't deny: Fantastick Honour, thou Enemy to Love, and Feaver of the Soul! Happy are they that want thee; whose Wills walk free, not fetter'd by a Tyrant, that bears a stubborn sway o'er every Passion. Instruct me Love, and sit upon my Tongue, that I may not deny or give too much. Sir, I must hear no more; your Words already have dy'd my Cheeks with Blushes: In them you'll find an Answer, better than what my Tongue can form. You've leave to hope for all that I dare give, or you can ask: I know I've said too much; but do not tax my Weakness.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: No, may your Hatred be equal to my Love, and my Despair exceed 'em both, if the cold Hermit, who spends his tedious hours in holy Duties, has purer Thoughts of Heav'n than I of you: Heav'n's fairest Model, on this I print my Vows, the Emblem of my Love: O, I cou'd talk forever! Each part about you is such a perfect Beauty, that it gives ev'ry thing a Tongue to sing its Praises.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, Dinner stays for your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It shall not long: Come, Sir, this fancy'd Love will lose it self in a full Glass or two of sparkling Wine.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: No, Madam, never; that can feed on nothing
But your full Beauties: I'm your happy Guest;
And Love invites me to the noblest Feast. Exeunt Fair. and Mar. Manet Bet.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: So I see, for all my Lady's reservedness, Mr. Fairly will find an easie Conquest: He's a true Soldier, I warrant him; he attacks with Vigor and Resolution: I hate those puny Lovers, that make a great Noise and to no purpose; they are all Powder, and no Shot: But who have we here? No new Guest surely.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Save you, gentle Damosel; do you appertain to this House?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hey-day! gentle and appertain! Some Beggar surely by her Cant.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: If you are a retainer to this Family, I must stipulate with you for a small Court'sie.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: A Gypsie, by my Maidenhead! This is the very Language of the Devil, (aside.) Thou'lt be burn'd for a Witch, my Life on't.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And thou hang'd for a Thief, Betty. She unmasks.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Murrain take you; Is't you! What Deeds of Darkness are you bound for, that you dare not show your Face?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Love, Betty; Love, the Soul of the Universe, and the great Business of our Creation. Here, carry this Letter to Willmot, and send Bellfont out hither. Nay, prithee be as private and quick as thou can'st. Exit Betty.

One wou'd think by her Conduct, my Lady did begin to be cloy'd with Mr. Willmot: If she does not give him enough of her before Night, he has the heart of Hercules: But here comes Bellfont. Now to th'other part of my Errant. Enter Bellfont.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I find a Debauch over-night, is often a Friend to a good stomach the next day: But to the Lady; if I can guess what business she has with me, the Devil take me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Save you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And you too, sweet Mistress, good handsome Shapes. Aside.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I'm come from a Ladyâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm very glad of it, if her Face be but answerable. Aside.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: That's most desperately in Loveâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With my sweet Person; and a Tongue like a Cherubim. Aside.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You're quick of apprehension, Sir: This Lady's ill Stars have plac'd her in the hands of a most severe Guardian, that has not a stricter eye over her Fortune than her Person.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And I'm to be th'adventurous Knight that is to release her: I'm glad of it; I love a Mistress that brings danger with her; it heightens our Imaginations, and makes us fall to in the end with a quicker Appetite.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, Sir: Love, like hers, is able to break through brazen Gates, and adamantine Locks: She has taken the danger of the Adventure upon her self; all your business is to prepare to meet her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But where, Child? Tell me where, and take this for thy Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You know the close Arbour, at the lower end of my L. Goodland's Grove?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As well as my own Thoughts. My Imagination's fir'd at it: We'll fancy it one of Venus's silent Groves, where she has entertain'd her lusty Soldier: The spreading Oaks shall cover us with their Shades, whose trembling Leaves shall whisper Tales of Love: The yielding Earth, warm'd by our close Embraces, shall feast our Senses with new knots of Flowers, which shall in various Colours spring about us, sweet as thy Lady's Breath, and sparkling as her Eyes: Each little Bird at ev'ry melting Kiss, shall eccho it round all the conscious Grove; and when our Souls lye drown'd in mutual Pleasures, great Jove himself shall gently smile upon us.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Pray', Sir, preserve your Raptures for a better occasion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well admonish'd: But prithee, my dear Angel, what time will this Goddess appear?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: At Three, Sir, this Afternoon most exactly; perhaps she may seem a little coy at first, to show she's a true Woman; but, Sir, you must put it home to her; you know she does not come there for nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And, faith, that's well remembred: but no more, I think I hear Company.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Be true and secret.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As true as Light, and secret as Darkness. Exit Alice. So, now if I had Willmot's Vow of Chastity upon me, what a fine condition were I in! But hold, here he comes; his Advice will be very necessary at present; for to speak the Truth, I have some scruples upon my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: How now, Harry; What, turn'd Flincher! How sullen thou look'st! Thou hast not got Fairly's Distemper upon thee, I hope; hast thou?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, 'Faith; and yet my Thoughts are at present upon a Woman.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Woman, Woman! Nothing but dear damn'd, bewitching Woman! How heavily wou'd our Hours move without 'em? The Glass it self wou'd he both dull and needless, did it not raise our Spirits up to Love: But, prithee, what Woman is this?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: What's her Name?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, 'Faith, not that neither.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Where lives she?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If I can tell, the Devil take me

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Is she handsome or ugly?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wish I knew; for in short, I never saw her in my Life.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Hey-day! Where the Devil hast thou been! Of all the comtemplative Lovers I e'er saw, thou art absolutely the most absurd. 'Plague upon thee for keeping me so long about a Castle in the Air, that's here and there, and no where. Farewell, and pray Heaven to set thee in thy right Wits again; for at present I have but small hopes of thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, prithee be not so hasty: Thou must know, Frank, that this very moment did I receive a Summons from an unknown Lady, to meet her at a certain Place upon a very pleasant Account. Now do I want thy Advice in this Matter: for to speak the Truth, for ought I know, this may be some ill-natur'd Devil, that has a Mind to betray me, and then prey upon my weakness.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Who was her Implement?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One that made no very ordinary appearance; only she was mask'd, and that heightens my Apprehensions.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Thou'rt a Fool: What Design can a Woman have but Love? Go, if thou'rt a Man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, th'Devil himself can't promote Fornication more vigorously than thou do'st: But where art thou bound in such haste? To no Woman I hope?

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Yes, 'Faith, Harry, I've a deal of Business upon my hands; two Bills to be answer'd before Night.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why art thou mad! Dost thou remember thy Obligations to Clarinda!

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Ay, and the Clause in it too: If I cou'd be private, it was to be of no force; and that Whore-Master that has not the Art of Secresie, deserves to be castrated.

sp.speaker: Bellf.
sp.p: Well, thou'lt ne'er leave.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Away, reserve thy Speeches for thy Lady; preach Abstinence to her, and try if she'll hearken to thee. Exeunt severally.

div.stage: SCENE, changes to my Lady Barter's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Bar.
sp.p: THou'rt a trusty Wench: But art thou sure 'twas to be this Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Madam, I heard 'em this very Morning with my own Ears.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Bar.
sp.p: But if Bellfont shou'd know Flavia now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: He has been here but twice since she came to Town; and I'm sure she 'scap'd his Eyes both times.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Well, if I can have the grace to deny him, I know he'll be for falling to't most eagerly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, if it were my Case, a kiss or two wou'd reconcile all.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Thou art a Fool, Wench, there is a time for all things; this hour for my revenge; there are enough in store for Love: O here he comes.

q.l: And just as our Bliss began with a Kiss,
He was dash'd with an ha, ha, haâ€”

sp.p: How dost thou, my dear Damnation?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Oh, sick, Mr. Willmot; abominably sick.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: And I was sent for to prescribe a Remedy; I have that will give you ease immediately: Nothing but a languishing fit of Love, occasion'd by too much fasting: Come, come, I have a Sovereign Remedy; by this, and this, I have.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Out upon you; you make me worse; Inconstancy has tainted every thing about you; those kisses are not mine; I feel your Lips still glowing with a false Adulterate heat; another Goddess now claims all your Heart, and you are grown an Heretick in Love.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Meer Enthusiasm this; the very Devil of Jealousie; and I'll lay it immediately, if thou'lt but come aside a little.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Hold, hold, you are so fiery on a suddain; how will you be able to answer this to my Rival? Remember your Promise this morning; for shame, no Grace in you? But, cou'd I think that you, who have been pamper'd thus long with the dainties of the Town, cou'd take up at last with a fulsome Country Barn-door Fowl; a thing, that's come up on purpose to offer some ignorant Fool or other the leavings of the lusty Coach-man and Butler.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: A pretty business this is like to be; whilst I'm mollifying my old Mistress, I shall lose my Assignation with my new one. (Aside) Why how angry you are at a piece of Innocent Courtship; can you think my Tongue Heart went together? A meer ragged Colt; so wild and skittish â€”

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: That, none but such a brisk young Fellow as your self, is able to tame her; I dare swear, no Man in England labours more industriously in his Generation, than you do.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Were ever the precious minutes of Love so unaccountably lost? Mrs. Alice, your Company will be dispenc'd with, for the present; Madam, give the word: Come, come, those Eyes are kind, tho' your Tongue has play'd the Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Well, I see you are irresistible; Alice, you may retire; but let us first have Mr. VVillmot's judgment of the Song I was so pleas'd with last night.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Madam, I know 'tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: What, before you have heard it?

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: You have, that's enough: for God's sake, Madam, Sir Siman may come home in the same time; and then, how shall we be answerable to our own Consciences, for the happy hours we have kiss'd away.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: No, no; my Lord and he don't usually part so soon. (Willmot aside) Alas, poor Flavia!

div.head: A SONG. in the Second Act, sung by Mrs. Knight.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: O How you Protest, and solemnly Lye,
Look humble, and fawn like an Ass!
I'm pleas'd I must own, whenever I see
A Lover that's brought to this pass.
But keep farther off, y'are naughty I fear;
I vow I will never yield to't:
You ask me in vain, for never I swear,
I never, no never will do't.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: For when the Deed's done, how quickly you go;
No more of the Lover remains.
In haste you depart, what e're we can do,
And stubbornly throw off your Chains:
Desist then in time, let's hear on't no more;
I vow I will never yield to't:
You promise, in vain you adore;
I never, no never will do't.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Well, Sir, how do you approve of it?

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: Extreamly well, Madam; only 'twas something too long.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: She has another that's shorter; will you hear that?

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: No; if I do, may my Ears sprout out, till they are as long as an Ass's.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon without.
sp.p: Lady Barter, Lady Barter; where are you, Honey?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: O Heavens! I hear Sir Simon's Voice; if he catches you, we are ruin'd: What will you do?

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: Do, Madam; what shall I do? 'Gad, I don't know what to do.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: There is but one way. Alice, go meet him, and detain him a little: Here, into this Closet, 'till he is gone; I know he won't stay long; an hour will be the most.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: (Aside) An hour! That's an whole Age with me at present, if I durst tell her as much. I can't have patience, Madam; let me fight my way out.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Ha! By no means; in there, if you love me.

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: But, good Madam, dispatch him as soon as you can, that I may make haste and follow him: Was ever Cuckold so impertinent? (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Leave me to deal with him. She locks him into her Closet.

div.stage: Enter Sir Simon, Alice, and Lawrence.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: entering] Hussie, hold your Tongue; what care I, if my Lord Mayor had sent to me; he is no Peer of the Realm, I hope: where's my Wife?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Here, Sir Simon, who has anger'd you, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No body, Honey; but honest Lawrence has brought me some Money, that's better: Now Lady mine, I'll give you leave to recover your last Wager, when you dare venture.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Wager, Sir! I'll venture what you dare, that Lawrence has not kiss'd one Wench, since he has been in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: In troth, thou art the merriest Thief always: but I'm sure thou wou'dst lose; and therefore I won't lay.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Indeed, but by your Worship's favour, she shou'd not: I am too old for 'em; the Gypsies hate me worse than hard labour; and to speak the truth, I shan't sue to them for a favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah! Wou'd all the young Men were of thy mind; but, come, Madam, can you think of nothing else to lose upon?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: I have another thing in my head; but it's so extravagant, you'll laugh at it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Out with it, if you dare, I'm for any humour at present.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Well; then my last Locket of Diamonds to an equal Stake, you don't remember every thing belonging to an House that's made of Iron? To help your Memory, you may write down all you can think on in my Table-Book; when you have done, return it me again, and in half an hours tine; I'll either yield, or prove that you've lost.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Laugh, quothe; ay, till my sides crack: but I'll reserve my Mirth, till I have won the Wager.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Have a care Sir; don't be too secure: there, begin when you please. Alice, what does VVillmot think of this now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Think, Madam? Were I in his Case, I shou'd cry my Eyes out for meer anger.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Let him: before I have done, I'll so mortifie him, that were he in Flavia's Arms, he shou'd be as cold as a thing of fourscore and ten.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But see, Madam, how busie my Master is; what can be your Ladyships meaning in this Wager?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Any thing to detain my Husband; besides, that first offer'd it self; and if Sir Simon's Memory does not strike too home, I have laid the foundations of another Scene that will be very diverting. Come, Sir, have you done?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Done! Ay, and won too; the Inventory of a Smith's Shop, can't be more particular: Here, peruse it, and by that time I return from my Lords, own that you have lost.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Be but a little patient, and this moment may decide it; who have you left there?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A Company of honest Fellows, only they want Titles.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Did VVillmot dine with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Always enquiring after that Mount-Dragon; yes, he Din'd there, but hardly stay'd till the Grace-Cup; a wicked Fellow that same: Lawrence, I warrant, we have more Cuckolds in our City of his making, than Knights of the Kings; the Devil and he are sharers in our Wives, one is contened with their Bodies, and t'other takes care of their Souls.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Take heed, Sir, he may chance to hear you; for to speak the truth, we have been together ever since Dinner; he's at this very present in the House.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Is he so, Jezebel? I'll have him hang'd then, for breaking into it; he'll give us a fine account at Tyburn of Whoring, and Sabbath breaking: Gadsbud, I smell him already; Lawrence thou must help me: Come come, tell me, where is he?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Don't be in a fury then: you must know, that after I had Din'd, not expecting you home till night, and being unwilling to set alone, I sent for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A fine Woman's Companion he is, indeed!

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: He came as I cou'd wish.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ay, Hell take him for it.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: And to be sincere, I found his Conversation so pleasant and charming, that I believe, had not you come in, we had not parted till Mid-night.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nor till to morrow Mid-night neither, nor this Month; these twelve Months; No, nor till the Moon dropt Mill-stones: 'Sbud, had he been a Lord, I cou'd have born it; there is some Honour in being a Nobleman's Cuckold: But tell me where he is, 'Gad I'll slice him into ten thousand pieces, and every Cuckold in London, shall have a bit as long as he'll hold out.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Why, dear Sir Simonâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Stand off, Adult'ress; thou smell'st rank of Harlot; I see my Horns plainly in thy Eyes: discover your Monster, or I'll pluck 'em out; they shall light no more lewd sinners to the deeds of darkness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Well then, since you won't be pacify'd, he's in my Closet.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Is he so? I'll fetch him out I'll warrant him. Alice, fetch down my great Sword; how now, what have you lock't him up? The Key, the Key?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Nay, good my Dear, the Wager?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy Tongue, I've lost already what I shall never recover. A Cuckold! A Cut-purse! 'Zounds, I shall be sport for Porters within these two days; if she does not laugh at me, may I be a Chronicl'd Wittol.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Laugh! Who that sees how credulous your jealousie is, can forbear? There, Sir, revise your Catalogue, and see if you can find a Key mention'd in it; a Key's made of Iron, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Mass, and she's in the right; I begin to cool again; no, no such thing: where's my Brains?

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: Do you think, if I had been so impudent as to transgress, I shou'd have wanted cunning to conceal it? No, I perceiv'd I had won, and made use of this trick to let you know it: you may take the Key; but if you find any thing there, besides the Practice of Piety, Dod upon the Commandments, and two or three Novels, I'll be Carted for a Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Take it! No, I won't wrong thy Innocence so much, as to mistrust it; a merry Thief, Lawrence; I wou'd not for twice the worth of the Wager, but have lost; here Hussie, take it, all pure Gold; take it I say, and treat VVillmot with it: Ha, ha, ha! I'm so pleas'd every foot she is frighting me thus. Sirrah, Sirrah, I'll pay you for this at night; the merry'st Jest, they shall certainly have it at my Lord's; one kiss, and then farewel. Come, Lawrence, you shall go with me, perhaps we may meet your Master Sir Arthur there. Allons, a Cuckold; ha, ha, ha! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lady Bar.
sp.p: So; now Alice, I believe you may release your Prisoner; nay, come Sir, what, afraid of your Mistress?

sp.speaker: VVillm.
sp.p: Something apprehensive of your Wit, Madam: now han't I the Heart to be angry with thee.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: What think you Sir of being cut out into Slices, wou'd your body hold out think you, that every Cuckold might have a bit.?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: It wou'd be hard to satisfy the Husbands I believe, but the Wives and I might agree upon easier terms.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Likely enough, nay come, here's no danger now, Alice fetch us some Wine, and a dish of sweet-meats, here's enough to pay for all, Sir Simon left it on purpose.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: The Devil's in her I think, I shall never get rid of her.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Lord what's the matter with you? You was eager enough before, who Squanders away the precious Minutes of love now? Alice, you may retire if you please, but besure lock the door after you.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Her kindness comes like a Miser's charity, when 'tis too late with a pox; what a delicious Morsel am I like to loose? Faith, my dear, I'm sorry I can stay no longer, but business â€”

sp.speaker: Dy. B.
sp.p: Business? What quit your pleasure for business?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Not absolutely quit child, but defer a little, that's all.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Nay but opportunityâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: We shall have enough, farewel.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Pray stay a little, you are going to another Mistress now Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Trust me I am not, I must be uncivil this time. Exit Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: And us'd accordingly the next; how wou'd some Women storm now to be like me forsaken?

q.l: But since our Sighs and Tears are spent in vain,
Neglected as I am, I'le ne'er complain.

div.head: SCENE I. A Grove.
div.stage: The Scene draws and discovers Belfont and Flavia,

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: NAY come, no more excuse â€¢ Madam, they are both vain and useless; or serve at most but to blow up the fire you'd quench. This hand that's softer far than Down or Roses, this yielding hand which could press for ever, declares you free and open in your Nature; Why then do you decline what you were made for, did you come here for this? Are these the Joys to which you did invite me? Did you for this deceive the care of your too watchful Guardians? You shou'd have left your foolish fears behind you, those fears that wrong you more than Argos cou'd, with all his hundred Eyes set to observe ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ ; nay if you are so peevish â€”

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Sir, as you are a Man, and bear that Nameâ€”

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Come come you have fool'd too long.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Good Sir be kinder to me.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Kinder than Lovers hearts can wish, but your own peevishness that has out-done the loss of twenty Maiden heads, still crosses all my endeavours, wou'd you be forc'd then Lady? It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Dear Sir, low as the earth I bow me to you, for pittys sake dare you think there's an Heaven and be thus cruel?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Hell and the Devil! This is beyond all madness, good fearful Lady, can you be thus forgetful? This Afternooon you dar'd me to this place, this happy place, that seems to court us to our own desires, then, then your modesty wou'd have become you, now 'tis meer Vanity and Affectation.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Believe me Sir, by all that's Good and Virtuous, I ne'er sent to you.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: That's very strange, but how then came you hither? Was it to gather Flowers or view your Beauties in yon' curling Stream, the time, the place, convincing proofs perswade me I am right.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: By Heaven and all the Heavens Saintsâ€” but as you are a Man inquire no farther, don't urge a Secret from me, that concerns my Honour.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Now do I want a little of Wilmot's impudence, to say the truth, I shall give but a lowzy account of this business to him, and yet I dare not, this must be more than counterfeit, confound the Devil that sent me hither, pride and the Pox still stick upon her, by Heaven she weeps, there's something more in this which I must know: Nay Lady dry those tears, they speak my shame that caus'd 'em; let your fears vanish with all my unchast thoughts, which thus I throw for ever from me, yet give me leave to think, though I am not the Man, you came to meet some other, that wou'd have prov'd more welcome; nay blush not Lady, for I'll ne'er betray you, my tongue shall rot first.

sp.speaker: Fla.
