sp.p: Let my tears thank you Sir, you speak a Nobleness that wants a name, and whate'er I can say will be too little; 'tis true I came to meet a Man, false and ungrateful, whose name Posterity will never find, but in the examples of a broken love, he has deceiv'd me, and I'll learn to hate him more than I ever lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Dull senseless Fool, to wrong such excellence and lose a Treasure Jove himself would sue for, I'm all o'fire again, to look upon her and not wish to enjoy her, is more than Man can do; and cou'd you Madam, be thus wondrous kind to one whose worth can never claim one favour from you, and yet be so severe, so cruel to me, who cannot live but in your Love, look on me Lady, I can do as much in a fair Ladies service, as the most large pretenders, and be a constant servant to your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Be virtuous too, and I shall truly love you, those happy Saints who in the age behind us, made up bright Stories for the times that follow, shall not be more esteem'd, more honour'd by me.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Very fine this, and I shall be a Saint, a good dull Saint, but such a Love will become us when we are old and honest; mean time let's court those Joys our youth is fond of, and lose our selves in pleasures where age sha'nt find us; nay prithee come, why shou'd you be thus peevish? Consider what you are.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Consider what you'd make me, this hour I grant I seem handsom to you, what shall I be the next? When I have melted all my Virgin Charms in the hot fire of Lust, the Plague it self will not be half so odious.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Nay fie no more; indeed you make me smile to see how prettily this fear becomes you; to me you shall be very fair as an Angel.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: To you I may be so, but to to the eye of Justice deform'd and crooked.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Was ever Woman so perverse before? What Eye can see? What Tongue inform against us? Who is there that can know it?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Our Consciences they are Witnesses, no art can silence, no power restrain when once provokt, they'l strike far louder than the tongue of envy; consider Sir a thousand Women may be had, ten thousand, and thank you too; Women who daily live in the full pride of Lust, and have out-run the Vices of all ages; why therefore shou'd you seek out my undoing? I never wrong'd or heard one thought against you, be juster Sir, be more a Man and show how Nobly you dare stand.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: If I but listen a little longer, she'll e'en perswade me I'm an Eunuch, and yet 'tis heaven to hear her speak.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed I came to meet a Lover, but not with one loose wanton thought about me; that Love which neither Fame nor Virtue shuns was never thought unchast, but you false Men, whose oaths are lighter than the Air receives 'em, have thrown it out of fashion; Why did I hope to find him Honest, who never knew what Faith or Honour meant.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Ha! I begin to smell something, this must be one of Wilmots Adventurers, he said indeed he had a couple to embark in, the Rogue has sprung a leak in the first, and so is disabl'd for any second service; your anger Madam does become you, for he who cou'd be false to so much worth, can ne'er be over wretched, give me his name, that for your sake, I may both scorn and hate him.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: When I have nam'd him, I have mention'd all that's lewd and treacherous, Wilmot, a name all modest Tongues must curse.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Ay 'tis so, none but that pamper'd Brute cou'd neglect such a delicate dish; I know him Madam, know him such a Gamester, such an high Fligher, he'd have shown no pity, why dar'd you trust your self and all your fears to such a Termagant?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: A steady Virtu's ne'er without a guard, he woo'd me oft to his unjust desires, but in such soft, such winning terms, that tho' I scorn'd to be his Whore, I wou'd have been the lawful partner of his Bed before the Sovereign Empress of the Universe, I heard of his Address to another, even then when he was courting me to all that's wicked, I fear'd to loose him, tho' in all appearance I ne'er cou'd hope to enjoy him lawfully, my fortune in the eye o'th' World, being much below his hopes, and therefore chose this way to let him know, that neither in Blood or Wealth I came behind my Rival; 'tis true I knew him bold and desperate, and cou'd not be too cautious of my Honour, which this shou'd have secured, had he once dar'd to offer violence; now Sir, if you e'er knew the the worth of Honour, or felt the fury of malicious Tongues, for once be more than Man and hide my shame.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Believe me Madam, so much my Tongue shall be from wronging what next Heaven I love, such goodness, that my own life shall not be dearer to me; who 'twas that sent me hither I can't conceive, but from my heart I thank 'em; I've found a Jewel equal to a Kingdom, and give me leave to wear you in my Soul, before the Seat of lust, but now enlighten'd with the bright beams of so much God-like Virtue, that Faith and Love ne'er found a seat more noble; here let me seat my Vows, the sincere vows of a new Convert.

div.stage: Whil'st Belfont is kissing her hand, Wilmot enters.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: It must be on this side, I'm sure: I was devilishly afraid of being snapt up, for I hear they are all in the Garden; I'm glad I escap'd so well as I did but now; had my Lady's stomach been so coming as mine, I shou'd not have kept touch here, and to balk her in the first Encounter would not be much to my Credit, as I take it. Ha! what's this I see? another leapt into my Saddle? are all my expectations come to this? How like a couple of wanton young Worms they look, that are lewdly clung together in a dewy Morning? But this shall untwist 'em. He draws his Sword, and runs up at Belf.

sp.speaker: Fl
sp.p: Ah, hah, hah!

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: How the Devil cam'st thou here? Is this the Lady gave thee such a kind Invitation? False Flavia.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Ingrateful Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Plague o' your hot head, what have you done, allarm'd the whole house?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Pox o' your hot blood, what have you done, layn with my Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Hold your rude tongue, or this shall silence it: Had thy Mother been half so honest, she had been a Saint e're now.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Thou art a Beast so much below my Anger, that I shall laugh at all thy impious tongue dares brand me with.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: For God's sake, Madam, think timely what to do; I hear 'em coming, and if they find you here, thÃ´ you are pure as Heaven, they'l think you black as Hell.

sp.speaker: Fl
sp.p: I'll retire. Sir, and trust my honour to your Conduct; a back door here behind leads into my Aunt's Garden. Exit Flavia.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: A fine day's work this, two hopeful Intreagues come to nothing; and what's worse, Clarinda will find me false, and be a very Tyrant: Owns, had I but tasted the Fruit, 'twou'd never vex me, but to have my teeth set on edge at the very sight on't does a little trouble me. Prithee Harry, did'st thou find her easie? Thou art much oblig'd to the advice my Coxcomb gave thee to day.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: For shame, have better Thoughts in thee; Truth it self is not streighter.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: That's likely: What did she come here for then?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: That's a mystery thou shalt be hereafter acquainted with; but who sent me hither, unless 'twas the Devil himself, I can't imagine.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: One that will be a Devil in time, I believe; my Lady Barter, by this Light it cou'd be no other.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: What, then I suppose she has been retaining your person in her Service the mean while.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Ay, a Vengeance take her, she has so; but such another Adventure won'd make me abjure the Flesh more heartily than ever I follow'd it, and turn down right honest again.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: It will become your Prudence.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Such damn'd Devices, Harry: but prethee how do I look?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Something Crest-fallen: But see, they're all coming, and my Lady Barter at the head of 'em, as I live.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Confound her, now shall I be worri'd to death.

div.stage: Enter Lady Barter, Clar. Marina, and Betty.

sp.speaker: L. Bar.
sp.p: It must be this way, Ladies, we are right I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: aside. Ay, the Devil take you, you are so; my Mistresses all up in Arms against me, and I not one lye ready for my Defence.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Look ye Ladies, here's a Gentleman I believe, can give us a better account of the Outcry: What say you, Mr. Wilmot?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmot here! I thought you had been at t'other end of the Town, paying some Money, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Why faith, Madam, I went with that design; but upon the fall of Guineas the Party was in an ill humour, and would not receive it!

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Unkindly done indeed; make you leave your Mistris, and to no purpose: They should stay long enough if I was you.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: As long as a peevish humour some Mistriss that had disappointed her Lover, and all the tenders of his Service: 'sdeath she'll betray all presently,

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Heark you, Madam, 'twas a fine Errand you sent me on; no more distressed Damsels? I'm a Man of Honour. aside to L. Barter.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Nay, I knew I should deserve your Thanks.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Which I want words to pay.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: The Devil plot you: I hate a mischievous Mistriss.

sp.speaker: L B.
sp.p: And I a Cormorant Lover, that flies at all without any mercy.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: But all the while, where can this Lady be? Betty, let's go seek her; for I must know who she is. aside to Betty.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'll follow your Ladyship. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: No pity in you, Madam? You may make up all yet if you please: So severe a Pennance for one fault?

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Do you feel it, Sir, are you sensible of it? This 'tis to be such a covetous Gamester, to ven â€¢â€¢â€¢ e so many Stakes at once: Is it come home to you at last? What, rise hungry from a full Feast, meerly because your mouth water'd at an idle bit in a corner.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I confess my fault, and own you have been too hard for me.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Well, I see you are penitent, and have done.

div.stage: Enter Lord Goodland, Sir Sim. Sir Arth. and Fairly.

sp.speaker: Lord Goodl.
sp.p: O here they are Marina, where's your Cousin?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: On the other side of the Grove, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: How now, Bully, what, naked amongst the Ladies? For shame, for shame; why this Sword drawn, Man?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: To pink your Coxcomb with, if you are impertinent. 'Sdeath, these are come in for a Reserve: There's nothing so odious to a disappointed Whoremaster, as a fantastical Cuckold. aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Prethee why so passionate, Man? I must laugh at a pretty Fancy
comes into my head: Thou look'st, methinks, like the Satyr of the Woods.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: And you like the Bull of the Mountains. Insufferable Coxcomb. aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Why Frank, thou art as ticklish and intractable as a Colt.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: And you as dull and dirty as an Ass.

sp.speaker: Fairl.
sp.p: Thou art not mad, Man, art thou?

sp.speaker: Wilm,
sp.p: I shall be presently, if these Worms bite a little longer.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Prithee be more temperate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, how wou'd you have a Gentleman behave himself, that is caught upon suspicion, and, as ill luck would have it, by his own Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Great pity you had no Closet to run into: Nay, thereby hangs a Tale, and I must laughâ€”But you must expect your Sins to come home to you by degrees; you young Fellows that live like Mice on others Meat must be caught in the Trap sometime or other.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'm sure it must be so, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'll plague him for't.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, here's a Lady I must present you to; you'll know her when you see her.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Death, Hell, and Damnation; I had rather see the Ghost of my Great-grandmother: Now will that ill-natur'd Dog betray all, and I shall be be banded about like a Tennis-ball, toss'd in a Blanket, it may be, before I get off. aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: O, here's your Mistriss, Wilmot; stick to her, Man, she'll teach you to be honest: you have a slippery piece to deal with, Madam, thÃ´ he may make a good Husband; for surely he that has such a love for other mens Wives, must have more than an ordinary Affection for his own.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: I find, Sir, the Maids can go down upon occasion, as well as the Wives; he shoots at all Marks; these Trees cou'd have witnessed it within these two hours.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, some Gentlemen within expect your Lordship.

sp.speaker: L. Good.
sp.p: Very well: They are return'd. Come Sir Simon, t'other Glass; 'twill make us sleep the sounder. Gentlemen, one Bottle will do us no hurt.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: We'll follow your Lordship.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Wilmot, what think you of a Song?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I have had Singing to day already, enough to put me out of Tune for this month.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Gallants, shall I propose one made by a Gentleman here present, in honour of a Lady in the company?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That will be very proper indeed Sir Arthur; we shall be all oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Come then, Fairly, you know best how to grace your own Works.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: What means the Booby?

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p:
The Song you made at Brussels man: Marina so pretty, so young and so witty; you Sung it to the company when the fat Spanish Officer drunk three full
Rummers to her nether Lip, and the tip of her left Ear.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: By Heav'n! the Fool's run mad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis what I fear'd, I find all men alke; one look's enough to blast our Reputations, and make us sport for Knaves and Drunkards. (aside.) I know not, Sir, in what I have encourag'd you to such a base unworthy act as this is, must my unhappy Name be the Companion of all your midnight Cups and lewd Debaucheries?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But hear me Madamâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, I have heard too much already. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: If thou wer'st not a fool, beneath my anger, I'd kick thee.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: I can't find what reason she has to be angry, unless she is jealous of her own praises.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Follow her man, one word or two will recover all, these little quarrels nourish Love, make it more strong and lasting.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: 'Tis but a short Fit like Heat-drops in Summer, that vanish as they fall.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I'll try my fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now I'm of a quite different opinion; quarrelling to beget love is like spending high to become rich.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Or rather, Madam, perpetual Peace is like a constant Sun, it scorches up what it shou'd feed and ripen; some angry minutes now and then intervening, like kindly showers render it brisk and lively.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Madam, my Master's Brother has sent for him to Hamstead, but he must speak with you before he goes.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: This is as I cou'd wish; dare you lye alone to Night after all this day's Villanies. aside to L. Barter.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Why, wou'd you be my Bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I know I don't deserve that favour, butâ€”

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: You have a Fool to deal with; Well, let me have the Serenade you so long promis'd, and thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: That then has made me all on fire. Exit L. Barter

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But I shall cool you if my Wits fail me not. aside

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Here comes Fairly again with War in his face; I wish I was well rid of him.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain, I may as well endeavour to smooth the face o'th' Sea, when the Winds rise highest, as calm her anger.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Mr. Fairly, a word in private; trust me, this is only a qualm of Conscience, a foolish perswasion that her Honour is touch'd; she'll sleep it off in a Night or two.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I wish it were no more.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: You'll find it nothing else, I have that in my head shall convince you, Sir Arthur shall do it, I'll set him on to Court her, the very thought of such a Lover will disarm her anger.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Any thing, Madam, to feed my hopes; but â€”

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Nay, no exceptions upon Love; retire you with Wilmot and Belfont, and leave me to manage the Knight.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You shall command me; Come, Wilmot, Wine is the best Physick for a Love-sick heart; let us to my Lord, he'll wonder at our stay. Belfont, you'll follow?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: A good proposal, Madam, shall I be your Squire?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: No, no good Sir, follow your Commander, I may help to lead you home if you get drunk anon.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I shall be very loving then.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: A good quality in a Drunkard. Ex. Wilm. Belf. and Fairly
Hold, Sir Arthur, I have a word or two for your Ear.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: I thought as much, that treacherous Dog has discover'd all: Madam, I beg your Pardon heartily; I must be submissive. aside.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: For what, Sir, I know nothing you have done stands in need of it?

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: That deserves it you mean, Madam; I own I was to blame, but before my Tongue shall be guilty of such another fault, I'll bite it off, and lay the bold offender at your feet.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: O, is that all? No fault at all Sir Arthur, it may turn much to your advantage, if you are wise.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: How's this? I have heard, indeed, the best way to step into a Woman's favour was to talk bawdy to her face; but that to tell bawdy Stories of her behind her back wou'd do, I never found before.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Why, but Sir Arthur, so contemplative in a Ladies company?

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: 'Tis so, she's fond of me already. (aside.) A little admiring your Ladiships good Nature, that's all.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: You shall say you have reason, if you'll lend me your Ear a little.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Adsbud, and my heart too.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Dare you venture any thing for a fair Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Dare I lye with a fair Lady?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: What think you of my Cozen Marina?

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Not amiss, Madam, though there are others at present Nameless that I think her equals. Pretty Soul, how cunningly she opens, I must help her forward a little. aside.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Not many, Sir: what wou'd you do to be possess'd of all her love can give?

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: More for what somebody else can give: What an odd way she has got to try me. aside.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: The Fool's mad surely, I must be plainer with him: You know, Sir Arthur, by those words you let fall but now, you have made an everlasting breach 'twixt her and Fairly, if you are the man the World takes you to be, you will not lose so favourable an opportunity; Ply her in her fury, and win her to your self, her Anger and your own Merits will plead irresistible for you: 'Tis a Friend's advice, and if you are wise you'll take it.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Hum: What a blunder was I like to have committed, it's not so well as I thought, and yet 'tis better than I expected too. Madam, the Counsel of the Wise must not be rejected, as such I look on yours, and will incontinently follow it.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: I secure you you'll succeed as you deserve.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Madam, I have liv'd too long to doubt it, but the rawness of the Evening begins to be a little dangerous, will your Ladiship honour me with your hand in?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: I'll follow you, Sir; I have a word or two for my Maid first. Ex. S. Ar. This will work her, or I'm mistaken, and make her fret out that musty humour. But now for my own business: Betty, hast thou got the Cloaths ready I borrow'd yesterday at my Lady Courtly's, with the Hat and Crevat?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes Madam; but what your Ladyship designs to do with 'em, I can't imagine.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: More than I have time to acquaint thee with at present: And will Flavia come say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: She will, Madam, and will stick at nothing your Ladyship can think of to plague Mr. Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: That's well; come in, and help to dress me, I shall be but a Bungler.

div.stage: Enter Wilmot and a Servant, with some Musick.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Here, Gentlemen, this is the Window; some brisk wanton Air or other, to quicken her Imagination; and then the Song I gave you.

lg.l: 'TWas within a Furlong of Edinbrough Town,
In the rosey time of Year when the Grass was down,
Sonny Jocky blith and gay
Said to Jenny, making Hay,
Let us fit a little, Dear, and prattle,
'Tis a soultry day.
He long had courted the black brown Maid;
But Jocky was a Wag and wou'd ne're consent to wed:
Which made her pish and phoo,
And cry it ne're shall do;
I cannot, cannot, cannot, wonnot, wonnot buckle to.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: He told her, Marriage was grown a meer Joke,
And that none wedded now, but the Scoundrel Folk:
Yet, my Dear, thou should'st prevail,
But I know not what I ail;
I shall dream of Clogs and silly Dogs
With Bottles at their Tails.
But I'll give thee Gloves and a Bongrace to wear,
And a pretty Filly foal, to ride out and take the Air,
If thou ne're wilt pish and phoo,
And cry it ne're shall do,
I cannot, cannot, cannot, wonnot. wonnot, buckle to.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: That you'll give me Trinkets, cry'd she, I believe;
But ah, what in return must your poor Jenny give?
When my Maiden Treasure's gone,
I must gang to London Town;
And roar and rant, and patch and paint,
And kiss for half a Crown;
Each drunken Bully oblige for pay,
And earn an hated Living an odious fulsome way.
No, no it ne're shall do;
For a Wife I'll be to you.
Or I cannot, cannot, cannot, wonnot, wonnot, buckle to.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: There, Sirs, let this express my Thanks. Exeunt Mus.

sp.speaker: L. Bar. in the Balcony.
sp.p: Who's there, Mr. Wilmot?

sp.speaker: Wilm,
sp.p: The very same, my dear Temptation; be quick, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: I'll see if the Family is secure, and send down Alice, immediately. Ex.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Do so, and I'll thank thee when I'm got in: No new Quirks, I hope, to mortifie me. Roger, I have no farther Service for thee now; I am glad thou dog'dst Sir Arthur so happily, the Discovery may be of use in time; you bid the Coachman drive home, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Yes and please your Worship, an hour since.

div.stage: Enter Clarinda in Man's Cloaths, with Musick. They place themselves under the Lady's Window.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: O, There he is; how like a Thief he looks! Come; begin; and if he dares touch you, be sure roar loud enough to alarm the whole house.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Ha, What's here, my Fidlers come back again? As I live, a new Covey, and a Rival; by this hand, a young smock-fac'd Rival. Roger, lend me thy Cudgel, I shall break their Cats guts, and spoil their Musick.

div.stage: as they are going to strike up, he falls in amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Oh, I'm ruin'd, I'm ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: What do you do here then, you Sleep-murderers? you that are good for nothing, but to raise the Husbands, when honester Men are in private with their Wives: Take that amongst you. beats 'em.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Murder, Murder; for God sake help, good people, Murder.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, they'll raise the Family, and I sha'nt be able to get in these two hours: Go, walk off, and be thankful.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, turn your fury this way; here's one able to oppose you with a nobler Weapon than that your Cowardice has made use of.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Why, who have we here, Monsieur Lawrit? Prithee Child; put up thy Sword; thou wilt cut thy fingers with it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Your Throat, Sir, rather, if you are so unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Why, thou dar'st not fight.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Follow, and try me.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Prithee, consider first, a small scratch in thy Face wou'd break thy Heart; and shou'dst thou ever come under the Surgeons hands, the very Smell of their Oyntments wou'd choak thee.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir; this is no fit time or place to talk in: If you are the Man you wou'd be thought, shew it; the Moon shines favourably upon us, and will direct our Swords.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Well, go on; I'll whip thee into a better humour before I have done. I'll first corrrect my Rival, and then for my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Alice in the Balcony.
sp.p: Hist! hist! Mr. Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Go forward, Sir, I have but a Word or two to exchange here, and I'll o'retake you.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: This is as I cou'd wish. (aside.) At the corner of the Street then I'll expect you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I'll be with you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What have you done, Sir? All the house is rais'd at the noise you have made: My Mistriss is afraid you have had some Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: No, no, nothing at all, Mrs. Alice; by that time you have compos'd the Family again, I'll return.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But you'll be long.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Not for the World.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Are you sure there is no quarrel: My Mistriss heard Murder cry'd out.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: None upon my honour; only some drunken Footmen had a mind to alarm the Watch.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well, you'll remember.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I'll ne're think more else. (Exit Alice.)

I begin most dismally to suspect I shall have no better fortune in the night, than I had in the day time: Those little twinckling Stars are all against me. I wish this young Rascal had been in one of his Fidler's Cases, before he came hither; he's little enough, I'm sure. Roger, thou may'st go home now, if thou wilt; though I have two Combats to be engag'd in, neither of 'em requires a Second. How now! nothing but Hobgoblins stirring this Night?

div.stage: Enter Clar. in her own Cloaths, and Flavia in Man's.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Be but resolute, and it's impossible he should know you.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: But shou'd he draw upon me, I have a natural Aversion to a naked sword.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: O, I have that will secure us, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: By this night, this bawdy night, ill favour'd night, my own natural Mistriss, and another young smooth fac'd Sinner: How sweet she is upon him too; Hell and the Devil.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Now is our time. But cou'd you be thus wondrous kind, all I possess comes short of a Reward.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: What shall I do? My young fighting Gamester must stay a little, if he has the courage he pretends, 'twill strengthen his patience.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Madam, I bear no Mercenary mind, I shall be more than paid in the possession of your love.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Which you must never hope for, young Gentleman, whilst I wear this.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmot! luckily met, you may do us a kindness, for this Gentleman, an old acquaintance of mine, and my self, are in great want of a Lodging for this Night; My Unkles House I dare not make use of at present, for some reasons you shall know hereafter: Can you advise us to any convenient place?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, the Round-House, the fittest place for Night-Walkers; unkind Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cl
sp.p: Uncivil Wilmot; farewel, Sir, if you are so surly.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Nay, but one word more; Who may this little Squire be?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: She has told you, Sir, already; one that is proud of nothing so much as her friendship, the noblest friendship Love; my Title to which I wou'd not forfeit for all the World can give me.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: 'sdeath! this is a Twin Brother to my t'other Jackanapes. Very fine, Madam; and for what does your Ladiship design me? Your day Service. This is to be the feeble Animal your Husband, and I that noble Creature your Gallant. I like your choice well, you Women oftentimes deal by your Lovers as your Clothes, any thing will serve at Night, but in the day time Art it self is at a loss to please you.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: This is a Language, Sir, I am not us'd to, therefore forbear, or I have that shall make you.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: With all my heart, for know, Sir, she's my Mistress, and you shall win her before you wear her: Come Sir, when you please, I'll fight on this score tho' 'twere in the Church. Draws.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Now, Madam, or all will be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you had best, you see I've got a weapon will strike as sure as yours, and I dare use it; I'll give occasion to no Midnight quarrels, to morrowâ€” Pulls out a Pistol.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Yes, to morrow his f â€¢ ars wiil have convey'd him far enough from my Sword.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Secure us both till then.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Ha, but where?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: In your own Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: How am I perplex'd? If I go with these I shall miss my other Spit-fire; and what is worse, disappoint my Lady. aside.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Nay, come Sir, conclude on something quickly.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: All the Devils in Hell are at work to Night to plague me. Madam, my Necessities require me abroad.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Lend us your Key then.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Bevis, lend you a Bed to lye with my Mistress in.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: I have warn'd you of that Name, Sir, once before, but to satisfie you, I swearâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: But who shall believe you, you young treacherous Dog?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p:
You may, Sir; we'll never do our Loves such wrong to over-run our fortunes, or taste one Joy before the Warrant of the Church has made it Lawful:
May I ne'r answer the expectations of a longing Virgin; may she still find me weak and unable, as if Nature had design'd me for a Womanâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: The Rogue professes heartily, but I shall be never the more secure of you then, you may give me the slip before morning.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: No, if I do, may my dear friend, whom equal to my life I love, after all my hopes and wishes, prove a meer Woman.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Well, whether I will or no, I must believe you; you know my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: My Lady Courtly's.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: This Key will open a passage by the Garden that will lead you to my Chambers; you'll find two Beds there, if you are not affraid to lye alone.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Trust to our honesty's.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: For the present I'm in haste, if I catch youâ€”

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Leave nothing of a Man about me; farewel Sir: (Exit Wilmot.) Ha, ha, ha: I protest, Madam, I was once affraid he'd have gone home with you.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: No, Girl, I had secur'd him for that, his Honour was engag'd, besides his assignation with my Lady, which will end much to his satisfaction if Betty has done her duty.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: I warrant she has, I gave her her Lesson, and she went to work very heartily.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Well, let us he moving, for when he finds he has lost his Antagonist he'll return in a fury. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: 'Tis as I fear'd, that young Rascal has given me the slip; but hang him, for this Night I'll lose the thoughts of him: Now for my old Sign. He whistles.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: In Sir, quickly, you know the Bedchamber; my Lady will be with you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Here's for thee, my pretty Iris, I have a better Toy for thy Mrs. Juno; pray Heaven she does not prove a Cloud again, and deceive me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, be quick and silent as you can; Sir Arthur is still abroad, and will come in this way I believe. (Exit Wilmot) So, when shou'd I have got so much under an honest Lady. I wonder; this Gentleman loves his Pleasures well, I believe, he always pays so heartily for them; he's no true Knight Errant tho', he never brings his Squire with him, that shou'd be entertaining his Damsel, whilst he is civil to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
sp.p: How now, Hussy, what makes you up so late? and at the Door too? some Roguery or other I warrant.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: O Heavens, my Master!

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Well, Alice, is the dear man come? Bless my Eyes! what have we here? My Husband come home? aside.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
sp.p: Ay, marry is he, and 'tis well for him too, for he might have had Horns as big as the Bull of Basan else before morning: Nay, Mistress, stir one foot and this shall fetch you back. What dear Man was this?â€” But hold, the Street is no proper place for my Enquiries, I'll defer them till I am got in; follow me both. Nay, Gentlewoman, I say I'll lead the way. Exit. Sir Simon

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Madam, What's to be done? He's in your Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: Why, I find that Devil Wit has left me at my greatest extremity.

div.stage: Scene changes to a Bed-chamber, and Wilmot in it.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I wish she'd come once, 'tis something melancholly sitting in the dark; I am as impatient as if I had never enjoy'd her, and yet Clarinda will not out of my thoughts; surely she can't be what she appears: O! I hear her coming. (Enter Sir Simon L. Barter) My Dear, I hope the Night, a constant friend to Loversâ€” As Sir Simon enters, Wilmot mistaking him for the Lady runs to embrace him; the Lady shrieks out, and Sir Simon stares first upon Wilmot, and then upon his Wife.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: By all my hopes, the nauseous Cuckold! aside.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
sp.p: Unbutton'd! and ready for the Engagement! I have jested to a fine purpose; Good Sir, never fret for the mattter, all shall be mended the next time. I own I am a Cuckold; nay, 'tis impossible I should be otherwise, for what can an Old man, with an handsom Wife, expect else: Here's one as much disappointed as your self. Well, Alice, is the dear Man come? O how the flesh itch'd then! And you are well acquainted with my Wives Bed-chamber: You can grope out your way in the dark, I warrant him, or any Cuckolds Chamber in London. O that Fornicating Nose, that smells out an hot Lady as a Dog does a proud Bitch!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Now for the honour of my Function. (aside.) O, Sir, are you here? I have been looking all over the House for you.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
sp.p: Have you so Mrs. Bawd, his experience needs none of your assistance, he knows his way himself you see.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: For Godsake, Sir, don't speak so loud, 'tis Mr. Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
sp.p: Not speak? Marry but I will, that all the Town may hear me as loud as Bow-Bell, if possibly, and ring a warning to all feeble Husbands, and super-annuated Batchellors.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you'll break the head of the best design that ever was laid, Mr. Wilmot, and a certain Lady in the House, will have reason to curse you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ay, so I hope they will, e'er I have done with 'em.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Why good Sir, neither of 'em never wrong'd you.

sp.speaker: Ly. Barter.
sp.p: aside.] What can her meaning be in this?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No no, Cuckoldom is no wrong indeed, a Blessing, a very Blessing, ill Cuckolds go to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Good Sir, be patient, and don't disappoint 'em thus.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Art not thou an impudent, unconscionable Quean? wou'd'st thou have me look on whilst he lies with my Wife? I must confess he is an able Artist,
and might teach me the knack of pleasing her too; but Hussy go you to the fore-dore, bawl out Murder as loud as you can, raise the Constable and his Watch, and bring 'em hither. Sir I shall hamper you, and provide another sort of lodging for you, than what you expected.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Hold Sir Simon, I wear a Sword, and can right my self; let her stir one step on that design, and this Minute shall be your last.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: So; the right humour of an Whore-master, first lie with the Wife, and then beat the Husband.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: How sorry will you be Sir, when you find what an injury you have done my Lady; you know Mr. Wilmot has along time apply'd himself to Madam Flavia; 'twas with her he was caught to day in the Grove; being disappointed there, he had a mind to try his fortune to night; I by her consent was to let him in, I did so, directed him to her chamber, but fearing he might loose himself in the dark, was willing to be his Guide; that made me so eager to get before your Worship, to prevent this very mistake, which has so unhappily discompos'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Hum, she'd never be so confident, if this was a lye, but what dear Man was that you enquired after, Wife? I wou'd fain know that.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Who shou'd it be but Sir Arthur, who is abroad at this unseasonable time of night, and for ought I know may have met with some mischance or other, the thoughts of which wou'd not let me sleep.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I doubt I have been too blame, this is the appearance of truth; and hussy, why cou'd not I know this before?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Still as I was going to speak Sir, your impatience interrupted me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmot, I'm sorry for the injury I have done you, and to make you some amends, I wish you good success; I hope you'll be too cunning for my Landlady, she was vilifying honour and quality with a pox t'other day; pray do you take a little pains with her Neece, and stamp an honourable Title upon her.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I'll do my best Sir; Insensible Brute how easily they gull him. aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Your pardon my dear, I'll beg in bed. where I shall with more ease obtain it,
For tho' most Wives in fury spend the day,
Approaching night bears all in mists away;
The yielding Bed disarms their rage, you ne'er
Shall find one Woman can be angry there.
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: FAith Frank thou must pardon me, for tho' my own circumstances will scarce admit of any mirth, I must laugh a little.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: 'Tis fit thou shou'd'st; nay I can scarce forbear laughing my self, and yet take heed Ned, I may be chance to be angry, very angry, a little provocation will make me quarrel with the best Friend I have.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Indeed you are rightly serv'd; never take warning, this 'tis to live at random, learn to be honest o'God's name, and live as becomes a Christian.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Hold Sir, tho' I give you leave to be merry, I can't allow you to be grave upon my misfortunes, live Honest as becomes a Christian; pox o' your morality, thou art certainly cut out for a dull Husband, and art consequently a predestinated Cukold; no from henceforth I proclaim open War to the whole Sex, and am firmly resolv'd, to Defame, Ravish and Debauch, every thing that bears the likeness of Woman, those that pretend to a great deal of Honour, and have but very little Beauty; I'll tickle till their Blood itches, bawk 'em my self, and then turn 'em out to my Footmen; the handsom ones that wou'd be thought great Fortunes, and are catching at rich Husbands, I'll first promise Marriage to, then Whore, and afterwards hire some lewd Lampooner to tell the Town on't; the Wives I'll first lie with, and then betray 'em to their Husbands; the Virgins that are Honest, and are proud on't, I'll maintain to be Hypocrites, and perswade the World that the worst of Whores, who are not Honest, nor wou'd be thought so, have more Honour than they.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A desperate resolution, I confess, and yet the next handsom face thou se'st will make the relapse.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: No, the Horse-pox take me if it does, but still my little Hector does not appear; I am sorry I mist him so unluckily last night; if he uses his Sword no better than he does his Pen, I am like to have an easy Conquest, I have received many a Billet-doux writ in a better hand than this Challenge.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Well, if there is any mischief done this morning, and I chance to fall into this Honourable quarrel of thine, tell Marina I die hers in spight of all her anger, which in few days wou'd have done the work of my Enemies Sword.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Tell her a pudding, I'll tell her thou di'st as a Man shou'd, with a Curse in thy mouth against the whole Sex; S'life 'tis nothing but our fear that maintains their pride and Stubbornness; are they not our Slaves by Nature? why then must we slavishly sue to them, for what we can command, and they themselves upon their knees wou'd offer, if we cou'd but learn to despise and neglect 'em.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Thou talk'st like a losing Gamester; but to thy Guard, Frank the Enemy approaches, now show how manfully thou dar'st stand, here's one will put thee to it.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: She has not much war in her heart I believe, She keeps her Sword in the Scabbard; good morrow pretty Mistress, whither so early this Morning.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: To gather Primroses and Dazies for my sweet-heart, farewel.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Short and quick, and yet she seems to be none of the wisest, one word more Lady.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O Sir, I dare stay no longer, my Mother will be angry with me.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: And where does thy Mother live, sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: In a Glass-house, upon the top of the Iron Mountain in Greenland.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: And she has sent thee into England of an Errant, pox on her, we had Fools enough here before, but why dost thou hide thy Face?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: To keep it from the Flies forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prithee Frank, let her alone, 'tis some Bedlam Fool or other.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Did you see my true love, pretty Gentleman? I believe you are he.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: No, the Devil take me if I am.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Was you never in love Sir?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Never with a Fool, Child.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why, then you must rise at Midnight, turn your self round three times, say your Prayers, wash your Face and hands in blue Milk, and thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You may go to bed again.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: May I so, Mrs. Nimble-chaps; let us walk a little farther this way Ned, she begins to grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Heark you Sir, stay a little, and I'll tell you your fortune; O fy, O fy, you have not been a bed all this night.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: If you had, you'd hid some Dazy roots under your pillow, hung your shoes out at the Window, and dreamt of me forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Then I shou'd have dreamt of a Fool, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then I shou'd have told you who you'll be Marry'd to, and what's become of the Tanner's Daughter you gave something to; I know what.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Ha, is the Fool turn'd Conjurer? Who in the Devil's Name art thou?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The Goldsmith's Wife that lost my Maiden-head the night before I was Married, can you tell me any News of it?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why Frank, art thou Bewitch'd?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My Aunt had a Daughter brought to bed in the Country, and was Married afterwards to a fat Lord's Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: The Devil take thee heartily, heartily, heartily.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My Mother had 20 Guineas and a new Gown for carrying a Mercers Neece to a Gentleman's Chamber, and I had ten more for taking care of her Child.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Death and Damnation!

sp.speaker: Cl
sp.p: O Sir, you must not Swear, if you do, the Puritans Widow will never trust you in her Chamber again.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: If thou art Flesh and Blood, and not the very Devil himself, as I begin to doubt, I will know who thou art before we part.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I am a little Fairy that challenge People in the night time, and run away from 'em when I have done.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Prithee Ned strike me a sound rap on the Pate, that I may be sure I am awake.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm a busie Tell-tale, that send Husbands home to catch other Men in Bed with their Wives.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: For which you shall be Whipt abundantly, Child.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm a little Night-Walker that get Mens Keys out of their Pockets, run into their Chambers, rifle their Closets, read all their Letters, and laugh at 'em when I have done; I'm a Jilt, a Fool, a Gipsie, and â€” your humble Servant. She unmasques her self.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And thy own Mistress, Frank.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: The Devil rather come to torment me; he cou'd never appear in a more hated Shape; but Madam, how dare you look in my Face again?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why Sir, is there any thing dangerous in it?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Don't you perceive it bent on mischief, and read in it an utter aversion to the whole Sex in general, and your self in particular?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Your pardon Sir, I can see no such alteration; to me your Eyes appear as wanton as ever, your Blood as high and amorous; I am so far from thinking you an Enemy to our Sex, that rather than lose time I know you can condescend to trifle away an hour or two with the Maid, when the Mistress is not at leisure, that Maid, Sir, your hungry Footman has scorn'd to touch; I can bring proof sufficient to confirm what I say.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: And reason good, were all Men of my mind, you Ladies, proud stubborn Ladies, should starve and pine to death for want of what your Maids enjoy at full; the Pleasures they can give, I'm sure, wou'd equal if not exceed what with such low submission, and slavish patience, we still sue to you for; they meet our Joys with equal vigour, and sit down sooner satisfied; Where's your fine trusty Squire, has he perform'd well to night, and cool'd your wanton Blood, or only stirr'd it, inflam'd it more, and rais'd your appetite; that's able to out-last the lusty service of a fat pamper'd Stallion?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, how froward he is, for want of rest I warrant him, you'l do well to go home and sleep, Sir, it does not become you, a Gentleman of your full Occupations, compar'd with whose abilities, the Husbands grow loathsom to their Wives, for whom our longing Virgins spend all their hours in silent wishes; bless me, what a Treasure I have lost, such an handsom well shaped Man, made on purpose to fill a Lady's Arms, and withall so modest and so innocent, a little whifling School-boy knows more than he does. Tell me, Sir, and tell me truly, What encouragement did you ever give me to build my Faith upon your Love; could I with reason hope to find you true? I'de as soon hope it from a common Strumpet. Dare you who are a perfect Inventory of loose and lazy Pleasures tax my Vertue with one thought of baseness?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I doubt I have been a Fool, but dare not own it; she'l grow too haughty if I once submit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You think me false; to shew how much I scorn you I'le own I am, own that I have lain all this night in the kind Arms of thy more worthy Rival; see where he comes, with whom one happy hour can yield more Joys than all your Life can reach at.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A brisk Youth on my word, I pitty thee Frank, but he's a Bait the handsomest Lady need not scorn to catch at.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Good luck, or bad, Madam. Aside to Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Good, good, he yields, Girl, my life on't.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Well, Pox on her, let her go, yet it vexes me that such a Snipper-snapper should win the day. Hark you Sir, I wish you much joy, you have had an happy night on't I hear, do you think you could hold out another; A Woman, Sir, a young wanton Woman, is a sort of stubborn Beast that requires both skill and strength to manage titely; How blue the Rogue looks under the Eyes!

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Your words, Sir, seem to bear some meaning in 'em I'm not acquainted with; howe're I hope she'l find me what she expected, true to her and love.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: I find your Merits larger than my Wishes, all that my Youth deserved or Love e're hop't for.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I shall grow mad anon. Madam I own you justly have preferr'd my Rival, and though, till lost, I never cou'd conceive how much I lov'd you; yet had you given me leave to read you, to read that honest noble Spirit within you, that Excellence which wou'd require whole Ages to scan o're truly, and admire with justice, you might have clear'd my Soul, made me confess that Men may love, and yet wear virtuous Minds.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do so, and then be happy, I have won the day, and all the World shan't part us; nay start not Sir, I am yet as clear as truth, like Virgin Paper not one stain upon me, here's one I'm sure will stand to what I say; Madam, confess your self.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: The same, that next to what I once desir'd equal to life, but now must never think of, is glad to see you what you are.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: That ever I shou'd be such a blind Puppy to be deceived with all my Wisdom and Experience by a pair of Breeches! Wild-Fire take you, had I but found you out, I had so firk't you, so trounc'd your Ladishipâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A pretty discovery this, indeed were I your Ladiship I'de preserve 'em as a Trophy, an hundred years hence they'l be as much admir'd as King Harry's Godpice, or the Sword that conquer'd France.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: By my Manhood a perfect Bully; see Ned what an handsom Leg she has, and withall a fine promising Back, I wish you well, Madam, but if your Husband is not an able Man, I gad you'l throw him off the Saddle.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p:
Well Sir, no more of this; you serv'd me yesterday a scurvy trick, and I have gaul'd you for it: With these, which now I find begin to grow uneasie
to me, I'll strive to lay aside all farther thoughts of Love, at least of you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Mr. Fairly, I find my Cousin's Anger does still sit heavy on you; Trust me, she shall be yours, do but come home and see, how much the Knight has laboured for you.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Madam, we are both deceiv'd, and I supplanted; for Belfont told me, she receiv'd his Courtship with all the easiness of a yielding Maid, seem'd pleas'd to hear him Speak, proud of his Praises, and granted more to him in one half hour, than my whole life could hope for.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: This is design'd, a very trap to catch you; Is she so quick, so full of Plots? I'll Plot her, lead her a Dance shall make her crafty Heart Ake, and on her Knees sue to be reconcil'd; this very morning it shall be done, it may be, give her Hand before the Parson: Sir Arthur is to furnish out a Consort to entertain us at his Uncle's; be you there and follow my directions, if I fail youâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Twill be a Sin to doubt you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Madam, I'm glad I have found you, such News!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: News! What News? Beshrew thy Heart thou hast frighten'd me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Your Mother Madam, your scolding furious old Motherâ€”

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What of her? Art thou Mad?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Is come to Town with the Knight that is to be your Husband: She is as loud as a March Wind, and as angry as an old Coughing Magistrate; Two of her Horses are killed, and a Coach Wheel broken through haste by the way: When the Gentleman that brought my Lord the News left her, she was just got out of a muddy Pool, and cleaning her old Velvet Gown, that has scarce seen Sun these thirty years.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I hope some peaceable Man or other will lay hold of her, before she comes to her Journeys end, and confine her for a Mad Woman.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I fear Madam you are in more danger of being confin'd; for she protests unless you Marry Sir Andrew, you shall die a Begger for any thing you are like to get in Warwickshire.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: So Mr. Wilmot, you see Providence never design'd us two to meet together in a Bed; She is a froward old Woman I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why, Madam, Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Who can help it Sir? She has me under Lock and Key; I mean, the most substantial part of me, the Ten Thousand Pound; I'm sure you are more a Man than to take the Baggage without the Bag.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Madam, you wrong my Love, I have enough for both.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your Pardon Sir; I' â€¢ l not tempt Fate so far, there are some hopes indeed a Woman may live Comfortable with her Husband, if she brings something to keep Love warm betwixt 'em; but otherwise I fear his Affections will cool faster than the Wedding Dinnerâ€” Nay, no more Promises and Protestations, you have won the Daughter, try now how you can prevail with the Mother: Let us home and consult my Lord; Come Mr. Fairly, who knows but we may all four meet in a Church before to morrow Noon yet.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You are all goodness, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Well, if I do loose theeâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You'll bless your good fortune.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I'll hang my self in one of thy Garters. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. Lord Goodland's House.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Well, Sir Arthur, thou art an happy Man; a Man of dispatch Gad, I never knew what I was good for before.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: My amorous Knight I see has Mew'd his Coat, and looks as stiff in his new Equipage, as a grave Ceremonious Gentleman Usher luckily Marry'd to his Amorous Lady: Do they then think to cure me by these means? I'll meet 'em in their Plots, and so confound 'em, that they shall curse their own Inventions. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Sir Ar:
sp.p: So, so, all this while now is she in a deep Contemplation of my Person; Her wonder has struck her Dumb; truth is, if she was so taken with me yesterday in my greasie Hat and broad Belt, How should she contain her self now, she views me in all my Glories? I'll make up to her. Madam, Th â€¢ s â€¢ bright beams of Love, which your Generosity threw upon my Unworthiness last night, have new Created me: You are the Mirrour of Perfection, the Burning Glass of Love, for like that your Beauties have contracted all my scatter'd Thoughts, which before were darted upon your whole Sex into one Circle, and you are now the Center of my Hopes. I gad, and that's fine. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O fie, Sir Arthur, this is the extremity of Gallantry; you make me blush for want of an answer, though I confess, silence will best become me; for I had better say nothing at all than speak too much.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Too much you never can, each Syllable you utter exceeds the Musick of the Sphears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I doubt, in the severity of your Wisdom, you'll tax my easiness, but who can help it? as the Play saith, None ever yet in Love were Wise.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: And all out on't are Fools: 'Tis the Business of the young, and Comfort of the old; 'tis what we are born for, the very thread on which our lives depend; for whilst Love continues the Soul and Body together, we Live; when that ceases, we return to Nothing, Madam, meer Dust and Ashes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well Sir, for the present I must retire; I dare stay no longer, I hear my Father coming this way; he must not know I'm up so soon, nor would I have him see you here.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Nay, I hope you'll grace our Musick this Morning?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: An hour hence Sir, I'll not fail you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar,
sp.p: You'll much Honour me. (Exit Marina.) Her Father! A lucky Thought's come into my Head; I reckon a little more Courtship will serve her turn; Suppose I apply my self to him, 'twill not be improper; he can object nothing against my Estate I'm sure, and 'tis that they say the old Folks chiefly mind.

sp.speaker: L. Goodl.
sp.p: My Sister indeed is so far in the right, they are never safe till well Married.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: My Lord, I am your Lordship's Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Goodl.
sp.p: This is an early visit, indeed, Sir Arthur, What Business can call you out of your Bed so soon?

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: A Business, my good Lord, that in time may keep me longer in it, with your Lordships good leave.

sp.speaker: L. Goodl.
sp.p: With mine Sir? Pray be plainer, I shall ne'er be wanting in any thing that may speak a Friends Mind.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: In confidence of which, my Lord, I'll proceed: Your Lordship has a Daughter, and can leave her a good Estate; my Father has left his Son a good one: I am very plain, my Lord; Now our Persons, and Estates, join'd together, will do much better than asunder: I am young, she is handsome, and both think it unreasonable we should lie any longer without a Bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: L. Goodl.
sp.p: This is plain indeed, Sir Arthur; and to speak the truth, I have nothing to object against your Proposals, if you can but persuade my Daughter to like 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: We are agreed already; Love has been long hatching betwixt us, though we knew not one anothers Minds till last night, at which time, like conceal'd Flames, it darted forth, and gave each an happy view of the others Soul.

sp.speaker: L. Goodl.
sp.p: Can this be earnest? Or is he in a Dream? Surely she can ne'er Love a Fool; Why not? Wise Men are out of Fashion with 'em now; Perhaps she has been told, the Fool still proves the kindest Husband, besides a large Estate, which, with his Person she may hope to govern, will hide all Faults: I'll take him as a gift of Fortune, and ease my Fears. (Aside.) Sir Arthur, you speak heartily, which shows an honest Mind; get but your Uncle's Consent, which, considering your dependance upon him, will be very necessary, and she is yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: That's as good as got already, my Lord; A Peer's Daughter! he'll never be against it; However, I'll take your Lordships Advice, and let him know what an Honour I am Born to. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Goodl.
sp.p: If Sir Simon will but settle his Estate upon him too, as I am told he has design'd, though I force her Inclinations a little, he shall be her Husband; 'Tis true, my Sisters violence is no way commendable, yet if a Parent's Advice and Authority is requisite in the petty Businessess of Life, it must be more than necessary in a thing of so great Concern.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wonder where my Cousin can be all this while, I would not willingly go by my self; My Father here still!

sp.speaker: L. Good.
sp.p: So early up, Marina; These are Lovers hours, whose busie Thoughts make their Sleep short and broken; Nay start not Daughter, I'm not come to chide you: Could you then hope a Business of such moment could long escape a careful Father's Ears. I know you are in Love, that Blush confesses it; nay come, no more Marina, you have got a Father's liking to confirm your choice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm amaz'd, but now 'twill be too late to hide my Thoughts, or trifle with his Knowledge. (Aside.) I own it Sir, but by that Love I Swear, it ne'er gave life to one vile Thought within me, or taught me to forgoe the fair Obedience I owe your Goodness.

sp.speaker: L. Good.
sp.p: I do believe thee; thou knowest we have none amongst us but have some Faults, we should be more than Men else, he has his share, but yet a modest Mind may learn to pardon 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, had he ten times more, (even them his Virtues would outweigh) so I might have your liking, I'de take him with 'em all.

sp.speaker: L. Good.
sp.p: Thou art all Sweetness, and shalt ever find me a kind indulgent Father to thy Wishes; He wants indeed a little of the Air and Courtliness the Town so much admires; but he has that will make a Wife's Life easie; a good Estate my Girl, and would his Uncle, having no other Child to enjoy it, but add his to it, Sir Arthur's Purse would much out-weigh their Wit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Heavens, Sir Arthur! To what a misery has my unhappy ignorance betray'd me? Fool that I was, not to perceive before, my Father's Words could never aim at Fairly, whose Faults, if he has any, are so small, they might with ease escape an old Mans Eye. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: L. Good.
sp.p: A Business of such consequence must ne'er be long delay'd; I'll to Sir Simon's Lodgings, and try what may done; if I find his Pulse beat time to our Desires, this Week thou art a Bride.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This Week Sir, 'tis too soon.

sp.speaker: L. Good.
sp.p: I know you are Modest, and loath to lay aside that Name of Virgin, believe me, Wench, an honest Wife's a Nobler; my care of thy well-doing shall speak my Love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis all too late, and my unhappy Anger has recoil'd back to work my own Destruction: O Fairly, Why was my Love so nice, or thine so forward?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How now Cosin, What in your Dumps? How does the Knight and you agree? I warrant you think this becomes you; Out upon't, a little Child that's Breeding Teeth would not be half so froward.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I must confess, 'tis fit you should be angry.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O is it so? Suppose my Servant like a valiant Knight, with a full Bumper in his Hand, maintains his Lady's worth against the boldest Drinker; must I forsooth think my self injur'd in it, as if his Glass had poison'd my fair Name, made it so loathsom that Bawds and Whores wou'd scorn it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Did you but know how miserable I am, you wou'd dissolve your anger into pitty, I have held a Snake in my unguarded Hand so long till I am stung to death; my Father encourag'd by that show of Love with which I met Sir Arthur's Courtship, has doom'd me to his Armsâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How say you? No, that's carrying the jest too far, Marry Sir Arthur? He is an ungracious old Man, if he offers it; my Mothers own Flesh and Blood I'le warrant him; when she comes up I'le have 'em both beg'd for a couple of unnatural old Fools; No I have a trick worth two of that; what say you Cosin? we are both concern'd; suppose we shou'd be too nimble for their Gravities, and prevent 'em? Mr. Fairly's to be had yet, and we shan't want opportunities this morning, by the Chaplain's assistance, of giving our Hands where our Hearts are.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No Cosin, the Curse of Disobedience will attend such rash Attempts; Honour and Duty both forbids us to dispute a Parents right; something I'le do for love, but know not what; after Sir Arthur's Musick's over I'le tell you more.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Here's Fairly coming, stay and be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not yet, 'twill look unseemly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Thou art an ungracious Girl, and were I Fairly I'de trouble my self no more about thee; Murrain take her, cou'd I but have perswaded her to it, I had had my ends; for truth is, since I am in some danger of losing him, I find this Fellow Wilmot sticks more in my Head than I imagin'd; and cou'd I have had her Company, I had made a sure Bargain on't; and put my self out of my Mothers reach, but I'le fit her for it, or my Wits shall fail me.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Well, Madam, what hopes?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why, at present I'me thinkingâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That if I live till to morrow, I shall be a day older.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: And if notâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I shall dye a Maid.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Proper thoughts enough for one in your condition.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But Madam pardon my impatience, where's Marina?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Considering what Masque she shall have at her Wedding; nay Sir, never start for the matter; you, like a whining Lover, must stand aloof, and let the bold Sir Arthur in the mean time attack her, board her in an instant, and now drive her like a Prize before him.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Be plainer Madam, I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I am sorry for it; know then, that whilst you play'd at bo-peep with the Daughter, he steer'd a safer Course, and apply'd himself to the Father; you may guess the rest, my Lord is a Discreet Man, and knows the Knight has got a good Estate.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Are then all my Hopes and your Promises come to this? I cou'd rave like a Mad-man; but he shall never carry it so.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, if he does, I'le dye in a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But howâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, no questions at present, unless I had more time to answer 'em; Go you home, I have a word or two for Betty's Ear, and will o're-take you, do you follow her Instructions, and leave the rest to me and Fortune.
sp.l: In spight of all their Arts we'll win the day.

l.hi: You are Loves Oracle, and I'll obey.

div.stage: SCENE draws, and discovers the Lady Barter and Sir Arthur instructing his Musick.

sp.speaker: Lady Ba.
sp.p: Come, come Cosin, you Lovers are so curious, were they to perform before the King, half these Instructions would have serv'd.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Madam, but one thing more, and we have done, be sure keep your Countenances. You Fidlers generally make worse Faces than Sir Martin; if your care in the performance, does but equal mine in the composure, I'me sure 'twill be very agreeable; And pretty Miss can you sing the Song I gave you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I thought to have met my Cosin here, Sir Arthur.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: She'l not be long Madam, Mrs. Flavia went for her, till they come in, and let's have the Song.

div.head: A Roundelau by Mr. Motteux.
div.l: MAN is for Woman made,
And Woman made for Man:
As the Spur is for the Jade,
As the Scabbard for the Blade,
As for digging is the Spade;
As for Liquor is the Can,
So Man's for Woman made,
And Woman made for Man.
As the Scepter to be sway'd,
As to Night the Serenade,
As for Pudding in the Pan,
As to cool us is the Fan,
So Man's for Woman made,
And Woman made for Man.
Be she Widdow, Wife, or Maid,
Be she wanton, be she staid,
Be she well or ill array'd,
Whore, Bawd, or Harrow-da
So Man's for Woman made,
And Woman made for Man.

div.stage: When that is ended, Fairly enters leading in Clarinda Masqut, and Wilmot, Flavia.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I now am happy, but tell me Madam, is't to your anger, or your love, or rather both, I owe this blessing? Ha! Are my Eyes open this Morning? Marina there and here too. Clarinda unmasques.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No Sir, but one that may do as well, if you'll but set your mind to it.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: How! Clarinda? who the Devil have I got then? Flavia unmasques.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: An humble Lover, that was forc'd to make use of this snareâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: To catch a Woodcock, a fine Morning's work this, Fairly prithee let us change; thy Mare has got the wrong Saddle.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I am all amazement, what cou'd you propose in this Madam?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What I have obtain'd, a good Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: How Marry'd!

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Marry'd!

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Marry'd! Marry'd! Yes Marry'd, is that such a wonder? Zouns, they stare upon me as if I was a Cuckold already.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Tho he is lost, this disappointment is some Satisfaction to me. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: This 'tis for a Man to leave his lawful vocation of Whoring, what a plague had I to do with Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Is this your Remedy Madam? you have now thrown me past all cure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You can't tell Sir, we are not the first that met upon compulsion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My miseries are now compleated. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: Bless me Mr. Wilmot, you'l have the Lord knows what with your Bride, her aunt will be extravagantly kind, old Bonds and Leases in abundance, besides her Husbands old Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Has she ever an halter for me too?

sp.speaker: Ly. B.
sp.p: And an old Cradel for the first Child, Heir apparent to all her Apostles Spoons and Diaper Napkins.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: You are wondrous civil, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: To my thinking you are not so merry as Men in your condition shou'd be, what! a couple of Weddings and not a dance? You are oblig'd to my care, I have provided some Musick for you, you'll be brisker at night I hope; Mr. Fairly, I am sorry for your disapointment, but who can help it, this Lady's Stars were against you; Marriages you know are made in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Dull blockhead, am I become his scorn too?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Had you given us timely notice, perhaps we might have born you company too, to make the pair Royal.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, Sir, I wou'd have Wedded to my Grave first: Did I want his impertinence to show me how much I have lost?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Ha! is all her kindness come to this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I had rather chuse a knot of Adders, mingle with Aspicks, or be confin'd to a Bed of Toads.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Ha, ha, what think you of a pair Royal, Sir Arthur; these are hard words.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Hard enough to break my heart, but Madamâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stand off, my breath shall blast you else; unkind Clarinda, did this become your friendship?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It became my Wisdom, however, if you'll do as we have done, the Gentlemen without, will say grace to you too, come Sir, come in.

div.stage: Enter Roger in a Black gown.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: The first of all his function I have cause to hate.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay Sir, pray be cover'd.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Not in my Master's presence Madam.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: How Roger! that I shou'd know a Pimp from a Parson.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If a Mock Marriage has thus discompos'd you, what can you expect from a real one?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Why that was it, had we been rightfully and orderly joyn'd together in the fear of the Lord, it wou'd have done.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Madam, I am much beholden to your wit, you have eas'd my fears, and this Lady is pleas'd to be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But Sir, there are more difficulties behind, my Fatherâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No more of that, 'twill make the Knight prick up his Ears again, I'll make him pay for what he has done already, your Father's an old Man, and must be rul'd. Sir Arthur, take courage, this is but a turn of Fortune; follow me home, I have a Plot in my head shall set all right again.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Madam, I'll attend you; besides my Uncle is at work for me, who has promis'd her a thundring joynture, and the Devil's in't if that wo'n't do.

q.l: For the wise tell us, that alone can move,
Sooner than all the Rhetorick of Love.
Come with full hands, if with success you'd woe,
'Tis ready money makes the Mare to go.

div.head: SCENE I. Goodland's House.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Ned bear thy self more like a Man.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Man I shall be a disgrace to the Name, if I sit down thus tamely, and let him bear her off before my face; I wear a Swordâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm
sp.p: Prithee wear a little discretion too, 'twill become thee better.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Bumsidel'd by a Fool, she is lost for ever, see where she comes, all bath'd in Tears, till now I never was in love with sorrow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Sir, all's past, my Father's deaf to all my prayers, just now the Lawyer was sent for to draw the Writings.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Or rather sign a Warrant for my execution.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: And you are making a whining speech before hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: All I can say but hastens on my ruine, he vows before to morrow's Sun is set, I shall be Sir Arthur's Wife, or no more call him Father.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Suppose you acquaint him with Mr. Fairly's pretensions Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I did so, but 'twas in vain; Sir Arthur and his Unkle have both his word, which he'll not break. (Enter Clarinda.) O Cozin what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What you might have done I told you, but what's now to be done is past my kaowledge,; nothing vexes me, but that we shou'd be over-reach'd by a fool.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Your only remedy Madam, now, will be patienceâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And repentance; I hope heartily she'll make him a Cuckold when she has him; what think you Mr. Wilmot? You see our Stars have design'd us both for Foolish Husbands.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I confess she has set you an ill example, but I hope you have more grace than to follow it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But my Motherâ€”

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Is a Transitory old Woman; that to day is, and to morrow is not; wou'd you betray your self, and the pleasures of Youth, to the humours of her doteage?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do but something then, that may make me in love with your wit, some pretty contrivance or other to break of this match, and I'll adore you, otherwise I have vow'd to follow her fortunes.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: 'Tis a rash vow, and ought not to be kept, what wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If I cou'd tell, I wou'd save your brains the labour of thinking.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I may as well hope to live upon rarifi'd air.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p:
Did one ever hear the like; do you take me for a Conjurer, if
you set me to show you a Trick or two, eat Fire, swallow a Knife, or the like, there might be some hopes, but this is a caseâ€”

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Your Wits are lost in; however, you know my mind, and will find me obstinate.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Madam, we are oblig'd to your care, though I fear all will prove in vain; and yet, as long as I wear a Sword, I can't despair, Love and this will do much.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Have better thoughts in you; here comes the jolly Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: She's a peevish fool, and shall pay for it when she's Married, ha! all these together; I don't like that, there is some Plot in the Wind I am afraid; that Fairly looks as surly as a Beef-eater, and yet when we are once married, I shall be more afraid of Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, come Sir Arthur, don't let us disturb you.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: We are teaching your Mistress how to carry her self against the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Pray God he does not teach her any carriage after it. aside. Madam, your Father calls for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll wait upon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Shall I attend you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The plague rather. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Say you so; she has a desperate Tongue of her own, and that is an ill sign, for they who are so free of that, are generally so of something else, and run proud at both ends: But hang't, I'll marry first, and consider of that afterwards.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I vow, Sir Arthur, you'll be happy to an infinite degree, she uses you as familiar already as if you had been married these six months.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But, Sir, do you think to carry it thus?

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Carry what? Does any one know what the Gentleman means?

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: To make you a Cuckold if you dare marry, stab you with your Wives Bodkin it may be, or stifle you in a Sack Posset.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Good lack, wou'd one think it? But pray, Sir, don't be angry, for I vow to God 'tis none of my seeking, marriage and hanging they sayâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come together sometimes, Sir, look to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: To cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Spoke like a friend; but I can't stay to thank you now, business makes me a little unmannerly at present, ha, ha, ha; however, I invite you all to my Wedding, Gentlemen; and so I take my leave. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: O, Harry, thou art come at a wish, here have been such strange doings, I have been married and unmarried again, Man, since I saw thee last.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What wou'd half the married People in England give they cou'd part so easily?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: It's an ill example, and shou'd not be encourag'd; but I have heard of all, and, Ned, I pity thy misfortune.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Your pity is all I can expect now, for we are past every thing else.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Belfont, thou knowest I told thee to day of a discovery Roger made, can't thy hot Brain draw something from thence?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Ha! aptly considered, a little pains may shape it into a good design: Ned, take courage, the Town's not lost yet, I have a stratagem forming in my head that may rout them all at last.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: At least I shall be indebted to your friendship.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: You say, Wilmot, you know her.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Her Father was my Coachman, till for his troublesome zeal, being a violent Precisian, I discharg'd him; I am sure a little Money will gain her.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: I am glad on't; what we before design'd for our mirth, may, if rightly manag'd, come attended with profit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmot, I see your Brains are in labour, I wish you an easie deliverance.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: The prospect of the reward will make all things easie.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If it succeeds we'll be merry, and have a Dance in Masquerade: Mr. Fairly, you told meâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I have them ready Madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Every one to their proper business then, I hear them coming this way; we must not be seen thus altogether, 'twill create suspicion.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Spight of their Arts I may prevail ere Night,
Since on my side both Wit and Beauty fight. Ex. omnes praeter Clar.

div.stage: Enter Lord Goodland, Marina, Sir Arthur, and a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Are the Writings drawn, say you?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: They are, my Lord, according to your Lordship's Order.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: And her Portion to be settled on her younger Children?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Well, we want nothing but Sir Simon's hand then: Sir Arthur, I see you are busie with your Mistress, she's a little froward at first, like a wanton Bird newly confin'd to a Cage, impatient of restraint, but you'll quickly learn to break her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: I shall do my endeavour my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Daughter no more, you'll prove a shame and sorrow to my Age, and make me wish I ne'r had been a Father.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good Sir, don't you by your unnatural severity make me doubt, whether or no I have a Child's interest in your affections.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Go, go, you know not when you are well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But Sir, to sacrifice me to a foolâ€”

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: There will be a couple of you well met if he is so.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
