sp.p: O, Cousin, are you here? My Wife told me you was gone to Mr. Mortgages Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: I met him, Sir, my Lord had sent for him before.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Come, Sir Simon, your hand, and the rest my Chaplain shall finish.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
sp.p: I know no reason why we might not make an end of all together this morning.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: No, good Sir, stay till to morrow, I must make a Song or two against the good hour; Besides, I have a design in my head for a Masque, and I can't get all ready so soon.

sp.speaker: Sir S.
sp.p: Fye, Cousin, they are trifles may be dispenc'd with.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: No, Sir, let him have his Will; besides, I expect my Sister to Night, she'll be a merry Guest amongst us.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Come, come, dry your Tears; Fortune may change, and work Miracles for you before to morrow. aside to Marina.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O, 'tis impossible; she's constant in her malice.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Mr. Belfont, I read Success in your Face.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Madam, you are in the right: I have brought a couple of Guests to the Wedding will prove very unwelcome to Sir Arthur, an old Miss of his, and her Mother, that may chance to forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I like your Plot well; it has some life in it: But how came you to bring 'em so soon?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Wilmot's Rogue of a Boy, for the sake of a little Mischief, had prepar'd 'em before hand: I met 'em at the Gate, and only fortified 'em with a few more Instructions.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Where is that Man of Sin, that Vessel of Uncleanness?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: With his bewitching Rachel, that wou'd rob me of my Help-meet.

sp.speaker: Sir. A.
sp.p: 'Oons! how came these here?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: That Whore of Babylon, Pitfall of Iniquity, and Lake of Perdition.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This is an excellent Dialect. aside to Belfont.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: What wou'd these People have?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Friend, we are come to seek a stray Sheep, a backsliding Zimriâ€”

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.p: Going to take to his unfaithful Bosom one of the Daughters of Canaan.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Whose carnal Mind, sated with the heavenly Manna, longs after the Egyptian Flesh-pots.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is indeed a pleasant Scene.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Does any one know these Creatures?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Yea, verily, that Son of Perdition, who having won to his embraces the Daughter of my Bosom, promis'd to take her to Wife in the face of the Congregation; and loe! now he leaveth her like an unholy thing.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, she seems to direct her Discourse to you; do you know her?

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Know her my Lord? yes, a little. No, my Lord, I never saw her in my life before.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Friend, I say unto thee, he has seen us both, and knows my Daughter; yea verily, the time is almost accomplisht since first he knew her.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: As the dumb Babe I now go withal can testifie against him.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: See, Madam, how Sir Simon foams.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: He has gap't twice; he'll speak anon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: aside.] ThÃ´ this Woman's Confidence, and my Nephew's Confusion, perswade me she is right, this is no time proper for my anger; perhaps a little Money may make all up again. Heark you, Woman, who set you on to do this?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Nothing but the Truth, to which my Conscience beareth Testimony.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Let me tell you, you don't take the right course of helping your selves; a word with you.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Methinks, Sir Arthur, you are not so kind as you shou'd be to an old Acquaintance, one you must needs know; she has your mark stampt upon her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, you are an happy man; you'll beget Sons and Daughters in abundance, that will be all Prophets and Teachers.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: 'Twas very lucky thÃ´, that she shou'd come just in the nick of time; had she staid but a day longer, she had lost you: Nay, Man, why so reserv'd? go, go, salute her with an holy kiss; see, she expects it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ar.
sp.p: Salute her with an horse-whip rather, I'm sure she deserves it.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: aside.] ThÃ´ there may be something in this, yet I smell a Plot, which they shall find too weakly laid.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: My Lord, may I never have the Honour of calling your Lordship Father, if ever I saw her above once in my life; and then I was so drunk that I could not stand.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Thy Money perish with thee, thou seed of Antichrist; wou'dst thou have me sell the Truth for that whcih perisheth like the Dung of the Earth? No, do us Justice, or else expect Judgment, which now I denounce against thee.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Nay, Mistris, you must not be loud: ThÃ´ I know all this to be a Lye, yet to silence you, I'll present your Daughter with 500 l. and if, as you say, she is with child, I'll settle an yearly hundred more upon that; and now after all their Arts, Sir Arthur, I hope to morrow to see you married to your own Content.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Peace; I am inexorable.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I undone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Thy words have the sweet Savour of Godliness in 'em: See the Money paid, and we are satisfied.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: This Afternoon, my Steward shall content you.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Damn'd mercenary Jade. Ex. Mother and Sarah.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Well, I have one Plot more, and if that fails me, I'll give over. aside.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Cousin, you see how stubborn my Daughter is, blinder than Fortune herself, which with an open and liberal hand seems to court her. Is there no way of winning her? You, I believe, are acquainted with her Thoughts better than I am.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Something to divert them a little, my Lord, might do much; you know she loves dancing well; some Neighbours without beg leave of your Lordship to present you with a Dance or two in Masquerade: It's an innocent Request, and I hope your Lordship will grant it.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: With all my heart; any thing to soften her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Within this half hour, Sir, they'll be ready: Mr. Belfont, a word with you.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Sir Simon, come, I'll make good my Promise to this Woman. Your Nephew is never the worse man for this Slip; a light touch of Youth: The best of Trees have their Blossoms before the Fruit appears: Time and Experience will blow it off.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I hope your Lordship will have no cause to repent of your Generosity.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: aside to Clar.) I admire your wit, Madam; I'll give them their Instructions immediately. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: The young people here are preparing a small Entertainment for us, a Dance or two; we'll give 'em way a little, our Company may disturb 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I'll follow your Lordship. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, you look on your self as secure now.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: As Friends and Fortune can make me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do you think my Cousin and Fairly have no Plots remaining.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: None worse than the last.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: See how you are deceiv'd now; for know, Sir, that within this hour they design to be married, in spight of all you, your Uncle, or my Lord can do: But since I first encouraged you in this Business, I reckon my honour as much engaged as yours, and will therefore teach you how to meet 'em in their own Devices, and so ensnare 'em, that you shall put it out of their power to plot ever after.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Dear Madam, let me adore you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Be patient a little; you know we are to have a Masque presently: Now whil'st all the rest are busie at their Sports, they are to draw off, and by the Chaplain's Assistance, who is of their Party, be knit so fast together, that all my Lord's Fury and Policy will never be able to separate them: This I had of Belfont just now, who thinks me a Friend to their Purposes. Now, Sir Arthur, what Tricks to prevent 'em?

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Tricks Madam, a thousand; I'll give my Lord warning of it before-hand.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That's not so well: For if they fail of this, they have such fruitful Inventions, that ten to one but they find out another before Night, and make sure work at last: Nothing to countermine 'em, and blow all their Imaginations about their Ears?

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: I can think of no surer Remedy, than what I have proposed.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It's a sign you are in Love, your Thoughts move so heavily. I'll tell you then. Suppose you should step into Fairly's place, and put the Change upon Marina? This is a piece of Wit wou'd force your way to her affections.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: But Madam, is this practicable?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nothing easier; I sent word by Belfont to Fairly, That Mariana would appear in a Turkish Vest, and advis'd him to be dress'd like an Indian: Now, to deceive 'em both, I'll tell her 'tis Fairly's desire she shou'd come in like a Shepherdess, and that he himself wou'd make choice of an Huntsman's Habit.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Now, Madam, I understand you; I have her in view, and if I lose the Scent, may Actaeon's Fate be mine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm glad you are so quick of Apprehension: Go, you must be as quick as you can.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.l: With equal Plots I'll meet their Plots, and fit
A Woman's cunning with a Womans wit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady Marina wou'd speak with you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I am for her, and do you follow Betty; I have been a long time in your debt, and if all you told me this morning is true, I may chance before night to acquit my self, if you'll be rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: In any thing, Madam, you may command me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That's well said, come along then, I see the Masquers coming, I'll be amongst 'em presently. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lord Goodland, Sir Simon with Fairly, Wilmot, Belfont, Lady Barter, Landlady, Flavia, and several Dancers, all in different Habits.

sp.speaker: L. Good.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies you much honour my house; I have some young people within, will not be long from you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Certainly these Gambols were first invented by some Whoremaster or other; a man can't know his own Wife, if she be amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Surely that must be my Landlady, I shou'd know her by the shake of her head; pray Madam what does your fancy aim at in your habit; it looks mighty Majestical.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Nothing under a Goddess, I'll assure you. Sir.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Goody Ceres, I believe in quest of her unlucky daughter.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: If I was so, you'd be the first I shou'd suspect for the Ravisher.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Now I shou'd rather take you, for an old Usurer's Wife, that under the covert of a Masque, have ventur'd to make one sally more out into the World, to view in others, the Sinful pleasures of your past youth, or a Court Bawd, come to debauch our Wives and Daughters, and rob our Markets to supply your Courtiers tables.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And what are you, a Citizen's Fore-man, that presuming upon your Mistrisses familiarity, have made bold with your Master's Wardrobe, through the vanity of appearing once in your life in a Character, to which you were never born; and which like a Player, you must within this half hour resign?

sp.speaker: Ly. Bar.
sp.p: By your giddy Fantastical dress, I more than half believe you are a French Monsieur, singling out some Lady in the company to be civil to.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: No, faith Madam, I am a plain downright English Cavalier, that wou'd fain be civil to 'em all.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Now, for ought I know, that may be my Wife yonder, and the fellow talking to her, a lewd young Whoremaster.

div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur on one side, on the other Clarinda, Marina and Betty.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: There he is, succeed and be happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Let me look about a little, there's my Shepherdess, but where's the Indian? O, I see him; poor fool, how his wits are rambling after the Turkish Lady; I must confess I am but little better than an Infidel to serve a Christian thus, but charity they say, first begins at home.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, this way lies your game, are not you Mr. Fairly?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Yes Child, the very same.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I can't but think how neatly we shall deceive that Fool, Sir Arthur; yonder he is they say, in the Indian habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Marry, he'll never have the heart to appear abroad again, in his own shape, after so signal a disapointment.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'll desire my Lord to call for a Dance, and then lead you the way, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: aside.) How infinitely am I oblig'd to Madam Clarinda! Well, this is such an excellent trick! Pray Heaven I contain my self before the Parson.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Come Gallants, you that are no Dancers, make room for those that are.

sp.speaker: Belf. to Clar.
sp.p: Has the bait took Madam?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I warrant him unable to do any more mischief for the future,

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies, be it known unto all present; that I Sir Arthur Stately in the County of Warwick, Baronet, have taken to be my Wedded Wife, this noble Lady; now whether it was with or without your consent, Madam, it matters not; however I hope you'll own you have been out-plotted; and that you have got a Wit for your Husband, and beg at once a blessing and pardon from my Lord. (She unmasques.) Cheats! Plots! Murders and Massacres! I am not married, never was married, and never will be married.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Sir, I can bring Witnesses who saw you give your hand to the Priest.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: They are all Heathen Rogues that say so he is no Priest, he is a Papist, a Monk, a Fryar, a Jesuit; he is the Devil's Confessor; or, now I think on't, he is Mr. Wilmot's Man Roger.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: My Lord best knows that, Sir; he has had the Honour of being his Chaplain these six years.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Why, Sir Arthur, what can be the meaning of this? Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: No, but I am married, and that is ten times worse.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Married, Sir? You jest sure.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: Ah! are you there? You have thrown a pretty blind Bargain upon my hands, I thank you; a Huntsman's Coat! a Fool's Coat: For your sake, I'll never trust a Woman again, but when she's asleep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is a miraculous Deliverance.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I find, Sir Arthur, your own distrust and too forward care has ruin'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: ThÃ´ I have no Heir of my own, Cousin, to inherit my Estate, there are many others that will better deserve it, than the servile Issue of a Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Sir A.
sp.p: So, I have not been married this half hour, and yet I find the Blessings of Wedlock coming thick upon me already.

sp.speaker: Fairl.
sp.p: Why, Sir Arthur, who could think you wou'd steal a Wedding thus? Here are some Friends amongst us, might have made up a Pair-Royal for Company sake, had you given us timely notice.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir Simon, show your self a Wise man to day, and to morrow I'll convince you that she's a better Wife than your Nephew deserves.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Mr. Fairly, I know your inclinations; take her, and with her an Old man's Blessing: Nothing but my obligations to Sir Arthur, stood betwixt you and your desires before: May you still lye upon the Downy Beds of Peace and Plenty, and know no Cares to interrupt your Joys.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Now am I villanously afraid to put you in mind of your Promise, for fear you shou'd be as good as your Word.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: No, don't try; For I doubt I have engaged my self for more than I shall be willing to pay.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Say you so? what if we compound then, and instead of a long, tedious, uneasie Life, be content with what a Month or two can give.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: No, Sir, That's like paying the Debt, without taking any Acquittance.

sp.speaker: L. C.
sp.p: Come, Cousin; I wish my Sister was here, to joyn your hands; for the present I'll supply her place: Doubt not her Consent; I have a Secret for her Ear will draw it from her.
Well, I see which way you are both going; and, as I have been hitherto the Companion of your Fortunes, cou'd I get this Lady's Consent, I wou'd still attend you.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: How, my Landlady's Neece; consider, Harry, thou art a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Were I an Emperor, she wou'd be the richest Jewel in my Crown.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Come, I know her mind; she can never part from so good Company.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I must be governed by my Aunt, thÃ´ now the Name dyes with her Authority: For know, Sir, my right Name is Lovell, a Name well known in the West of England; the occasion of my Disguise, I can scarce confess without Blushes: I had often seen Mr Wilmot at the Bath, and must own I lov'd him; 'twas that drew me to London, with a Design of offering him my Person and a considerable Fortune, if his Behavior had any ways encouraged me to hope he would accept it; but I now perceive his Stars had pointed him out a nobler Choice.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Or rather, mine, to compleat my happiness, reserv'd you for me.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: Madam, I hope your Goodness will pardon those Incivilities my Ignorance forc'd me upon.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: They are too small to stand in need of any Apology.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Come, I can read in all your Faces what your Desires are; go in, and let my Chaplain make 'em lawful.

sp.speaker: L. Bart.
sp.p: To my thinking, Mr. Wilmot, you look like a condemn'd Malefactor, that, just before Execution, is going to give the Spectators an account of the Sins which brought him to that unlucky end.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: No, Madam, I am admiring what it should be, that, considering my natural Inclinations, could keep me so long from it.

sp.speaker: Fairl.
sp.l: In fancy'd Joys our Vigorous Youth we lose,
And empty Shadows for the Substance choose:
Wanton we rove, and in variety
Fondly conceive Love's noblest Treasures ly.
But when experienc'd years have turn'd the Stream,
And Wisdom rais'd us from our golden Dream,
Then we confess, t'insure a happy Life,
No Blessing's equal to a Virtuous Wife.
